back: A rhythm of execution.
original_definition: A rhythm of execution

back: A project acceleration and collaboration technique whereby any team member is authorized to modify any project work product or deliverable, thus emphasizing team-wide ownership and accountability.
original_definition: A project acceleration and collaboration technique whereby any team member is authorized to modify any project work product or deliverable, thus emphasizing team-wide ownership and accountability

back: The practice of delivering feature increments immediately to customers, often through the use of small batches of work and automation technology.
original_definition: The practice of delivering feature increments immediately to customers, often through the use of small batches of work and automation technology

back: A practice in which each team member’s work products are frequently integrated and validated with one another.
original_definition: A practice in which each team member’s work products are frequently integrated and validated with one another

back: A team that includes practitioners with all the skills necessary to deliver valuable product increments.
original_definition: A team that includes practitioners with all the skills necessary to deliver valuable product increments

front: What is Crystal Family of Methodologies?
back: A collection of lightweight agile software development methods focused on adaptability to a particular circumstance.
original_definition: A collection of lightweight agile software development methods focused on adaptability to a particular circumstance

back: A brief, daily collaboration meeting in which the team reviews progress from the previous day, declares intentions for the current day, and highlights any obstacles encountered or anticipated.
original_definition: A brief, daily collaboration meeting in which the team reviews progress from the previous day, declares intentions for the current day, and highlights any obstacles encountered or anticipated

back: A team’s checklist of all the criteria required to be met so that a deliverable can be considered ready for customer use.
original_definition: A team’s checklist of all the criteria required to be met so that a deliverable can be considered ready for customer use

back: A team’s checklist for a user-centric requirement that has all the information the team needs to be able to begin working on it.
original_definition: A team’s checklist for a user-centric requirement that has all the information the team needs to be able to begin working on it

back: A collection of practices for creating a smooth flow of delivery by improving collaboration between development and operations staff.
original_definition: A collection of practices for creating a smooth flow of delivery by improving collaboration between development and operations staff

back: A process decision framework that enables simplified process decisions around incremental and iterative solution delivery.
original_definition: A process decision framework that enables simplified process decisions around incremental and iterative solution delivery

back: A process that challenges underlying values and assumptions in order to better elaborate root causes and devise improved countermeasures rather than focusing only on symptoms.
original_definition: A process that challenges underlying values and assumptions in order to better elaborate root causes and devise improved countermeasures rather than focusing only on symptoms

front: What is Dynamic Systems Development Method (DSDM)?
back: An agile project delivery framework.
original_definition: An agile project delivery framework

back: Openly credited as the first agile method that contains a specific component no other methods have: the focus on delivering multiple measurable value requirements to stakeholders.
original_definition: Openly credited as the first agile method that contains a specific component no other methods have: the focus on delivering multiple measurable value requirements to stakeholders

back: An agile software development method that leads to higher quality software, a greater responsiveness to changing customer requirements, and more frequent releases in shorter cycles.
original_definition: An agile software development method that leads to higher quality software, a greater responsiveness to changing customer requirements, and more frequent releases in shorter cycles

back: A lightweight agile software development method driven from the perspective of features valued by clients.
original_definition: A lightweight agile software development method driven from the perspective of features valued by clients

back: A product that is suitable for its intended purpose.
original_definition: A product that is suitable for its intended purpose

back: A product that is usable in its current form to achieve its intended purpose.
original_definition: A product that is usable in its current form to achieve its intended purpose

back: The coach for a team and service request manager working in a continuous flow or Kanban context.
original_definition: The coach for a team and service request manager working in a continuous flow or Kanban context

back: A basic system or structure of ideas or facts that support an approach.
original_definition: A basic system or structure of ideas or facts that support an approach

back: A specific behavior that a product or service should perform.
original_definition: A specific behavior that a product or service should perform

back: A specific function that a system or application is required to perform. Typically represented in a functional specifications document.
original_definition: A specific function that a system or application is required to perform. Typically represented in a functional specifications document

back: A strategy or policy deployment method.
original_definition: A strategy or policy deployment method

back: A combination of two or more agile and non-agile elements, having a non-agile end result.
original_definition: A combination of two or more agile and non-agile elements, having a non-agile end result

back: An organizational improvement model that is named for the five phases it describes: initiating, diagnosing, establishing, acting, and learning.
original_definition: An organizational improvement model that is named for the five phases it describes: initiating, diagnosing, establishing, acting, and learning

back: A strategic planning technique that acts as a roadmap to the organization while building new products.
original_definition: A strategic planning technique that acts as a roadmap to the organization while building new products

back: An obstacle that prevents the team from achieving its objectives.
original_definition: An obstacle that prevents the team from achieving its objectives

back: A functional, tested, and accepted deliverable that is a subset of the overall project outcome.
original_definition: A functional, tested, and accepted deliverable that is a subset of the overall project outcome

back: An approach that provides finished deliverables that the customer may be able to use immediately.
original_definition: An approach that provides finished deliverables that the customer may be able to use immediately

back: A visible, physical display that provides information to the rest of the organization enabling up- to-the-minute knowledge sharing without having to disturb the team.
original_definition: A visible, physical display that provides information to the rest of the organization enabling up- to-the-minute knowledge sharing without having to disturb the team

back: Refers to a person with a single deep area of specialization and no interest or skill in the rest of the skills required by the team.
original_definition: Refers to a person with a single deep area of specialization and no interest or skill in the rest of the skills required by the team

back: A timeboxed cycle of development on a product or deliverable in which all of the work that is needed to deliver value is performed.
original_definition: A timeboxed cycle of development on a product or deliverable in which all of the work that is needed to deliver value is performed

back: An approach that allows feedback for unfinished work to improve and modify that work.
original_definition: An approach that allows feedback for unfinished work to improve and modify that work

back: Events aimed at improvement of the system.
original_definition: Events aimed at improvement of the system

back: A visualization tool that enables improvements to the flow of work by making bottlenecks and work quantities visible.
original_definition: A visualization tool that enables improvements to the flow of work by making bottlenecks and work quantities visible

back: An agile method inspired by the original Kanban inventory control system and used specifically for knowledge work.
original_definition: An agile method inspired by the original Kanban inventory control system and used specifically for knowledge work

back: Large-Scale Scrum is a product development framework that extends Scrum with scaling guidelines while preserving the original purposes of Scrum.
original_definition: Large-Scale Scrum is a product development framework that extends Scrum with scaling guidelines while preserving the original purposes of Scrum

back: Lean software development is an adaptation of lean manufacturing principles and practices to the software development domain and is based on a set of principles and practices for achieving quality, speed, and customer alignment.
original_definition: Lean software development is an adaptation of lean manufacturing principles and practices to the software development domain and is based on a set of principles and practices for achieving quality, speed, and customer alignment

back: The process through which a product is imagined, created, and put into use.
original_definition: The process through which a product is imagined, created, and put into use

back: A technique in which multiple team members focus simultaneously and coordinate their contributions on a particular work item.
original_definition: A technique in which multiple team members focus simultaneously and coordinate their contributions on a particular work item

back: The preferences of an organization on a set of scales characterized by the following core values: exploration versus execution, speed versus stability, quantity versus quality, and flexibility versus predictability.
original_definition: The preferences of an organization on a set of scales characterized by the following core values: exploration versus execution, speed versus stability, quantity versus quality, and flexibility versus predictability

back: A comprehensive, cyclic, and structured approach for transitioning individuals, groups, and organizations from the current state to a future state with intended business benefits.
original_definition: A comprehensive, cyclic, and structured approach for transitioning individuals, groups, and organizations from the current state to a future state with intended business benefits

back: Pair work that is focused on programming.
original_definition: Pair work that is focused on programming

back: A technique of pairing two team members to work simultaneously on the same work item.
original_definition: A technique of pairing two team members to work simultaneously on the same work item

back: An archetype user representing a set of similar end users described with their goals, motivations, and representative personal characteristics.
original_definition: An archetype user representing a set of similar end users described with their goals, motivations, and representative personal characteristics

back: A planned course correction designed to test a new hypothesis about the product or strategy.
original_definition: A planned course correction designed to test a new hypothesis about the product or strategy

back: An iterative management method used in organizations to facilitate the control and continual improvement of processes and products.
original_definition: An iterative management method used in organizations to facilitate the control and continual improvement of processes and products

back: An approach to work management that utilizes a work plan and management of that work plan throughout the life cycle of a project.
original_definition: An approach to work management that utilizes a work plan and management of that work plan throughout the life cycle of a project

back: A more traditional approach, with the bulk of planning occurring up-front, then executing in a single pass; a sequential process.
original_definition: A more traditional approach, with the bulk of planning occurring up-front, then executing in a single pass; a sequential process

back: A management structure that standardizes the project-related governance processes and facilitates the sharing of resources, methodologies, tools, and techniques.
original_definition: A management structure that standardizes the project-related governance processes and facilitates the sharing of resources, methodologies, tools, and techniques

back: An ordered list of user-centric requirements that a team maintains for a product.
original_definition: An ordered list of user-centric requirements that a team maintains for a product

back: A person responsible for maximizing the value of the product and who is ultimately responsible and accountable for the end product that is built.
original_definition: A person responsible for maximizing the value of the product and who is ultimately responsible and accountable for the end product that is built

back: The iterative process of increasing the level of detail in a project management plan as greater amounts of information and more accurate estimates become available.
original_definition: The iterative process of increasing the level of detail in a project management plan as greater amounts of information and more accurate estimates become available

back: A product quality technique whereby the design of a product is improved by enhancing its maintainability and other desired attributes without altering its expected behavior.
original_definition: A product quality technique whereby the design of a product is improved by enhancing its maintainability and other desired attributes without altering its expected behavior

back: A regularly occurring workshop in which participants explore their work and results in order to improve both process and product.
original_definition: A regularly occurring workshop in which participants explore their work and results in order to improve both process and product

back: An iterative planning technique in which the work to be accomplished in the near term is planned in detail, while the work in the future is planned at a higher level.
original_definition: An iterative planning technique in which the work to be accomplished in the near term is planned in detail, while the work in the future is planned at a higher level

back: A knowledge base of integrated patterns for enterprise-scale lean–agile development.
original_definition: A knowledge base of integrated patterns for enterprise-scale lean–agile development

back: An agile framework for developing and sustaining complex products, with specific roles, events, and artifacts.
original_definition: An agile framework for developing and sustaining complex products, with specific roles, events, and artifacts

back: A management framework that emerges when teams employ Scrum as the chosen way of working and use the Kanban Method as a lens through which to view, understand, and continuously improve how they work.
original_definition: A management framework that emerges when teams employ Scrum as the chosen way of working and use the Kanban Method as a lens through which to view, understand, and continuously improve how they work

back: An information radiator that is utilized to manage the product and sprint backlogs and show the flow of work and its bottlenecks.
original_definition: An information radiator that is utilized to manage the product and sprint backlogs and show the flow of work and its bottlenecks

back: The coach of the development team and process owner in the Scrum framework. Removes obstacles, facilitates productive events and defends the team from disruptions.
original_definition: The coach of the development team and process owner in the Scrum framework. Removes obstacles, facilitates productive events and defends the team from disruptions

back: A technique to operate Scrum at scale for multiple teams working on the same product, coordinating discussions of progress on their interdependencies, and focusing on how to integrate the delivery of software, especially in areas of overlap.
original_definition: A technique to operate Scrum at scale for multiple teams working on the same product, coordinating discussions of progress on their interdependencies, and focusing on how to integrate the delivery of software, especially in areas of overlap

back: Describes the combination of development team, scrum master, and product owner used in Scrum.
original_definition: Describes the combination of development team, scrum master, and product owner used in Scrum

back: A cross-functional team in which people fluidly assume leadership as needed to achieve the team’s objectives.
original_definition: A cross-functional team in which people fluidly assume leadership as needed to achieve the team’s objectives

back: The practice of leading through service to the team, by focusing on understanding and addressing the needs and development of team members in order to enable the highest possible team performance.
original_definition: The practice of leading through service to the team, by focusing on understanding and addressing the needs and development of team members in order to enable the highest possible team performance

back: The person responsible for ordering service requests to maximize value in a continuous flow or Kanban environment.
original_definition: The person responsible for ordering service requests to maximize value in a continuous flow or Kanban environment

back: An organization structured in such a way that it only manages to contribute a subset of the aspects required for delivering value to customers. For contrast, see Value Stream.
original_definition: An organization structured in such a way that it only manages to contribute a subset of the aspects required for delivering value to customers. For contrast, see Value Stream

back: The practice of attempting to solve problems by just using specific predefined methods, without challenging the methods in light of experience.
original_definition: The practice of attempting to solve problems by just using specific predefined methods, without challenging the methods in light of experience

back: The practice of using a lightweight set of tests to ensure that the most important functions of the system under development work as intended.
original_definition: The practice of using a lightweight set of tests to ensure that the most important functions of the system under development work as intended

back: A collaborative approach to defining requirements and business-oriented functional tests for software products based on capturing and illustrating requirements using realistic examples instead of abstract statements.
original_definition: A collaborative approach to defining requirements and business-oriented functional tests for software products based on capturing and illustrating requirements using realistic examples instead of abstract statements

back: A short time interval within a project, usually of fixed length, during which a team conducts research or prototypes an aspect of a solution to prove its viability.
original_definition: A short time interval within a project, usually of fixed length, during which a team conducts research or prototypes an aspect of a solution to prove its viability

back: Describes a timeboxed iteration in Scrum.
original_definition: Describes a timeboxed iteration in Scrum

back: A list of work items identified by the Scrum team to be completed during the Scrum sprint.
original_definition: A list of work items identified by the Scrum team to be completed during the Scrum sprint

back: A collaborative event in Scrum in which the Scrum team plans the work for the current sprint.
original_definition: A collaborative event in Scrum in which the Scrum team plans the work for the current sprint

back: A unit-less measure used in relative user story estimation techniques.
original_definition: A unit-less measure used in relative user story estimation techniques

back: A technique in which multiple team members focus collectively on resolving a specific impediment.
original_definition: A technique in which multiple team members focus collectively on resolving a specific impediment

back: The deferred cost of work not done at an earlier point in the product life cycle.
original_definition: The deferred cost of work not done at an earlier point in the product life cycle

back: A technique where tests are defined before work is begun, so that work in progress is validated continuously, enabling work with a zero defect mindset.
original_definition: A technique where tests are defined before work is begun, so that work in progress is validated continuously, enabling work with a zero defect mindset

back: A fixed period of time, for example, 1 week, 1 fortnight, 3 weeks, or 1 month.
original_definition: A fixed period of time, for example, 1 week, 1 fortnight, 3 weeks, or 1 month

back: Refers to a person with one deep area of specialization and broad ability in the rest of the skills required by the team.
original_definition: Refers to a person with one deep area of specialization and broad ability in the rest of the skills required by the team

back: A brief description of deliverable value for a specific user. It is a promise for a conversation to clarify details.
original_definition: A brief description of deliverable value for a specific user. It is a promise for a conversation to clarify details

back: A visual practice for organizing work into a useful model to help understand the sets of high- value features to be created over time, identify omissions in the backlog, and effectively plan releases that deliver value to users.
original_definition: A visual practice for organizing work into a useful model to help understand the sets of high- value features to be created over time, identify omissions in the backlog, and effectively plan releases that deliver value to users

back: The process of enhancing the user experience by focusing on improving the usability and accessibility to be found in the interaction between the user and the product.
original_definition: The process of enhancing the user experience by focusing on improving the usability and accessibility to be found in the interaction between the user and the product

back: An organizational construct that focuses on the flow of value to customers through the delivery of specific products or services.
original_definition: An organizational construct that focuses on the flow of value to customers through the delivery of specific products or services

back: A lean enterprise technique used to document, analyze, and improve the flow of information or materials required to produce a product or service for a customer.
original_definition: A lean enterprise technique used to document, analyze, and improve the flow of information or materials required to produce a product or service for a customer

back: Machine behavior and function that exhibits human intelligence and behavior. More specifically, it is the ability of machines to perceive, understand, learn, make decisions, converse, and develop intuition.

Also known as 'strong AI,' this refers to systems enabled with cognitive capabilities and mental dexterity that mimic humans, allowing them to generalize knowledge across domains and adapt to changes.
AI systems designed to use technologies to perform specific, limited tasks (e.g., chatbots, facial recognition) and cannot be applied to other tasks.
The concept of machines and humans working together to enhance, rather than replace, human tasks.
The act of repetition focused on handling the same inputs to produce the same outputs; it does not require intelligence and cannot handle variability.
The ability to understand the environment and process the data provided by that environment.
Enabling a machine to recognize patterns and use that recognition to forecast future events.
Using perceived information and lessons from pattern observation to make decisions and develop plans.
A set of methods and processes that enable computer systems to learn patterns from stored data using algorithms.
Algorithms learn by being trained on examples of labeled data (e.g., email filtering).
Algorithms are provided with unlabeled data and must discover hidden patterns or groupings without human intervention.
A method where machines learn through trial-and-error approaches.
An ML algorithm simulating the human brain's neural connections to encode learning.
The use of many layers of interconnected artificial neurons in a neural network to enable complicated learning.
The ability of systems to accurately identify and classify images, recognize faces, and detect specific objects within images or videos.
Applications that understand and process speech and written words.
Allows computers to communicate with humans in a conversational flow.
Physical and virtual systems that can accomplish a task, reach a goal, and interact with surroundings with minimal human involvement.

front: What is Conversation and Human Interaction in AI?
back: Machines and humans interacting in conversational ways via voice, text, or image.
Systems that learn through trial and error to achieve a specific objective or goal (e.g., game playing, resource optimization).
Using ML to develop a profile of an individual that adapts over time to provide personalized services or content.

front: What is Pattern and Anomaly Detection?
back: Using ML to review patterns in data to identify outliers or anomalies (e.g., fraud detection).
Using ML to understand past behaviors to determine the probability of a future outcome.
Distinguishing and classifying different images, video, audio, and objects.
The application of ML techniques to create new data or content based on learned patterns.
Large, pretrained models focused on a general domain (like language or vision) that serve as a starting base for AI systems.
Deep learning neural network models trained on massive data sets to understand, summarize, generate, and predict new content.
Models that track relationships in sequential data (like a sentence) to learn order and meaning.
Foundational models utilizing neural networks to transform input prompts into text, images, or audio.
A request or natural language instruction a user submits to a GenAI system to perform a task.
The process of training staff to write effective prompts and using specialists to fine-tune underlying LLMs to optimize response quality.
When a GenAI system provides an incorrect, nonsensical, or false output not based on training data or reality.
An approach leveraging a data repository of custom/proprietary information to enhance the accuracy and relevance of AI-generated content.
The process of training a model on a specific data set to adjust parameters so it aligns better with specific tasks or domains.
A statistical technique studying relationships among dependent and independent variables.
Classification models that categorize data based on variables, resembling a tree structure where branches are options and leaves are results.

front: What is Time Series in AI?
back: A subset of forecasting where a model attempts to predict an event over a time range.
Grouping data that share characteristics or qualities.

front: What is Human in the Loop (HITL)?
back: The integration of human oversight and judgment in AI processes to interpret outputs and ensure alignment with goals.
Systems that provide insights into how AI decisions are made to allow for scrutiny.

front: What is Inference in the context of AI privacy?
back: Using seemingly innocuous data to predict private attributes about an individual.
Incorrect or misleading information provided by AI due to errors in processing, data quality, or algorithms (unintentional).
Intentionally spreading false information or manipulating data sources to steer AI toward incorrect outputs.
Hyper-realistic audio, video, and images created using deep learning to make it appear individuals are saying or doing things they never did.
Techniques where models are exposed to malicious inputs (adversarial examples) during training to enhance resilience against attacks.

The set of activities performed to support delivery of solutions that align to business objectives and provide continuous value to the organization. It encompasses value-oriented approaches, practices, disciplines, and mindsets.

front: What is a Business Analysis Practitioner?
back: Any individual doing the work of business analysis, regardless of title.
The impetus for a change in an organization, based on an existing problem or opportunity, which provides the rationale for initiating a program or project.
A concept unique to each organization involving tangible and intangible elements; considered the return (time, money, goods, or intangibles) for something exchanged.
The ability to add value or achieve objectives in an organization through a function, process, service, or other proficiency.
A project or action taken to attain an opportunity or solve a problem.

front: What is a Problem in business analysis?
back: An internal or external environmental area causing detriment to the organization (e.g., lost revenue, dissatisfied customers, noncompliance).

front: What is an Opportunity in business analysis?
back: An uncertainty that would have a positive effect on a product or solution.
Something produced to deliver measurable business value to meet the business need and stakeholder expectations.
An artifact that is produced, is quantifiable, and can be either an end item in itself or a component item.
Individuals, groups, or organizations that may impact, are impacted by, or have yet to be impacted by a problem or opportunity under assessment.
A condition or capability that is necessary to be present in a product, service, or result to satisfy a business need.
Describe the higher-level needs of the organization, such as business issues or opportunities, reasons for a project, and measurable goals.
Describe the needs of a stakeholder or stakeholder group.
Describe the features, functions, and characteristics of the product, service, or result that will meet business and stakeholder requirements.
Describe the behaviors of the product, including actions, processes, and interactions.
Describe the environmental conditions or qualities required for the product to be effective (e.g., security, reliability).
Describe temporary capabilities (e.g., data conversion, training) needed to transition from the current state to the future state.
A set of conditions that are defined and must be met before deliverables or features captured in user stories are accepted.
A series of conditions the entire team agrees to complete before an item is considered sufficiently developed for acceptance by business stakeholders.
A set of related requirements typically described by a short phrase.
A one- or two-sentence description written from the viewpoint of the actor that describes a needed function, usually in the format 'as an <actor>, I want to <function>, so that I can <benefit>'.
A large user story that is too big to construct in an iteration.
The features and functions that characterize a product, service, or result.
An objective statement about a problem or opportunity that includes the statement itself, the situation facing the organization, and the resulting impact.
A documented economic feasibility study used to establish validity of the benefits to be delivered by a portfolio component, program, or project.
Measurable representation of the goals the business is seeking to achieve.
A technique for understanding the difference between current capabilities and needed capabilities.
An assessment occurring as the organization approaches solution deployment to evaluate if the organization is prepared for transition and to integrate the solution.
An in-depth analysis of proposed solutions based on factors like operational, technology, cost-effectiveness, and time feasibility.
Defines the activities required to transition from the current to a future state.
A guiding framework for conducting activities needed to transition from a current state to a future state.
The activity of drawing out information from stakeholders and other sources to understand business needs, problems, or opportunities.
A group creativity technique that allows large numbers of ideas to be classified into groups for review and analysis.
A group elicitation technique led by a facilitator to quickly identify a list of ideas for a specific topic.
An approach to brainstorming where participants contribute ideas by writing them down individually and sharing anonymously to encourage broader participation.
A collaborative game where participants use imaginary cash to 'buy' preferred features, helping to prioritize requirements.
A model used to analyze capabilities in a current or future state, mapping problems to root causes and proposed capabilities.
A method of identifying possible root causes of a problem by iteratively asking 'why'.
An elicitation technique bringing together prequalified stakeholders to learn about their expectations and attitudes toward a proposed product.
A tool used to identify and analyze driving forces (supporting change) and restraining forces (opposing change) impacting a decision.
A formal or informal approach to elicit information by asking prepared or spontaneous questions.
A prioritization technique standing for 'Must have,' 'Should have,' 'Could have,' and 'Won't have'.
A technique to view people in their environments to see how they perform tasks or processes.
A visual representation of stakeholder analysis showing multiple layers of engagement (e.g., core team, affected groups, external stakeholders).
A fictional character representing a particular user profile or stakeholder segment to generate empathy and understanding.
A visual tool where the trunk represents infrastructure/requirements, branches represent primary functions, and leaves represent features.
Obtaining early feedback by providing a model (low-fidelity or high-fidelity) of the expected product before building it.
A decision-making process for dealing with uncertainty by delaying decisions until the last responsible moment.
A method that arranges user activities along a horizontal axis (narrative flow) and tasks/stories along a vertical axis (priority) to provide context for the backlog.
A method of collecting information using sets of questions from a large number of respondents.
A low-fidelity drawing of a proposed application showing key elements of the user interface and layout.
Policies, standards, or regulations that constrain how the business operates (e.g., calculations, limits).
An ordered list of product backlog items, typically expressed as user stories, representing stakeholder requirements.
A high-level view of features and functionality along with the sequence in which they will be delivered.

front: What is a Requirements Traceability Matrix (RTM)?
back: A grid identifying bidirectional links between solution requirements, their origin (business/stakeholder requirements), and deliverables.

front: What is a Stakeholder Engagement Assessment Matrix?
back: A matrix comparing current stakeholder engagement levels against desired levels (e.g., Unaware, Resistant, Neutral, Supportive, Leading).
Comparison of actual/planned practices to those of comparable organizations to identify best practices and measure performance.
Financial analysis tool determining benefits provided by a project against its costs.
Metrics defined by leadership used to evaluate progress toward meeting targets or objectives.
The process of determining if an initiative should continue, be stopped, or if a solution should be released.
The attitude of being in a hurry to complete a solution while overlooking potential problems or mistakes.
Any programmatic tool that can intelligently automate, assist, or augment humans by receiving inputs and creating content or providing predictive results.
A type of AI where the user prompts the AI model with a question or command, and the model responds by generating output such as text, images, or video.
AI that relies heavily on machine learning and uses historical and real-time data to forecast future trends, events, or behaviors.

A subset of AI that involves training algorithms to learn patterns and make decisions from data. Instead of being explicitly programmed, these algorithms improve their performance and accuracy as they process more data.

A computational model inspired by the structure and function of the human brain. It consists of interconnected layers of nodes, or neurons, that process and transmit information. Each neuron receives inputs, applies a mathematical function, and passes the result to the next layer. Through training, neural networks learn to recognize patterns and make predictions or decisions based on input data.

front: What is a Large Language Model (LLM)?
back: A sophisticated neural network designed to understand and generate human language. Trained on vast amounts of text data, LLMs can perform various tasks such as answering questions, translating languages, summarizing text, and generating creative content.

front: What is a Graphics Processing Unit (GPU)?
back: Hardware particularly adept at handling the complex mathematical algorithms crucial for machine learning, thereby accelerating the development and adoption of AI technologies.

front: What is a Project Management Office (PMO)?
back: Focuses on project execution, governance, resource management, and adherence to standards. Provides oversight and governance necessary to manage AI projects.

front: What is a Transformation Management Office (TMO)?
back: A specialized team created to oversee and manage large-scale transformation efforts. Focuses on the broader organizational change and transformation processes, ensuring AI adoption is seamlessly integrated into the company's culture and operations.

Includes portfolio managers, program managers, and project managers. They are the frontline executors of transformation initiatives responsible for ensuring individual projects within a transformation are delivered successfully.
Portfolio, Program, and Project Management.

front: What are Trailblazers in AI adoption?
back: Organizations using AI in over 50% of their project work.

front: What are Explorers in AI adoption?
back: Organizations using AI in less than 15% of their projects.
Metrics used to track progress and assess the impact of AI initiatives.

front: What is Accuracy in AI performance metrics?
back: Measures how often the AI model makes correct predictions or classifications.

front: What is Precision in AI performance metrics?
back: Measures the proportion of true positive results among all positive predictions.

front: What is Recall in AI performance metrics?
back: Measures the proportion of true positive results among all actual positives.
A balanced measure of precision and recall, useful when dealing with imbalanced data sets.
A metric used to evaluate the performance of regression models.

front: What is Root Mean Square Error (RMSE)?
back: A metric used to evaluate the performance of regression models.
Measures the financial benefits of AI implementation against the costs.
A metric used in customer experience ROI calculations.

front: What is Total Cost of Ownership (TCO)?
back: Includes up-front costs plus ongoing costs of maintaining AI solutions (cloud storage, model retraining, HR) minus operational savings.

front: What is Employee Net Promoter Score (ENPS)?
back: Employee satisfaction and likelihood to recommend AI tools.
Customer satisfaction scores for AI-assisted interactions.
Customer loyalty and likelihood to recommend AI-driven services.
Ease of AI-driven interactions for customers.

An iterative continuous improvement process that begins with planning improvements, implementing them, checking results against predefined metrics, acting on findings to adjust, and then reviewing overall impact.
Specific, Measurable, Achievable, Relevant, and Time-bound objectives.

front: What is a Service Level Agreement (SLA)?
back: Contracts that outline scope of work, deliverables, timelines, performance metrics, and payment terms with vendors.

front: What is an Application Programming Interface (API)?
back: Technical interface used for data exchange and system integration.

front: What is COBIT (Control Objectives for Information and Related Technologies)?
back: A comprehensive framework for IT management and governance that provides an audit framework to assess the effectiveness of IT governance and management practices.
original_term: COBIT (Control Objectives for Information and Related Technologies)

front: What is ITIL (Information Technology Infrastructure Library)?
back: Focuses on IT service management and best practices to deliver high-quality services.

front: What is TOGAF (The Open Group Architecture Framework)?
back: An enterprise architecture methodology that provides a structured approach to design, plan, implement, and govern an enterprise's IT architecture.
Part of TOGAF; ensures audits assess alignment of IT systems with business objectives.
A structured way from the National Institute of Standards and Technology to evaluate and manage cybersecurity risks within an organization.
A global standard for Information Security Management Systems (ISMS) outlining best practices for establishing, implementing, and maintaining a security framework.
An enterprise architecture framework that provides a structured approach to organizing and analyzing an organization's IT systems.

front: What are Information Security Management Systems (ISMS)?
back: Systems outlined by ISO 27001 for protecting an organization's information.

front: What is GDPR (General Data Protection Regulation)?
back: European data protection regulation.

front: What is CCPA (California Consumer Privacy Act)?
back: California data privacy regulation.

front: What is HIPAA (Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act)?
back: US healthcare data protection regulation.
original_term: HIPAA (Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act)

back: Periods of reduced funding and interest in AI development (historical term).
Policies and standards for data quality, security, and compliance throughout the project life cycle.
The quality, availability, and management of data within an organization.
The process of managing organizational and cultural changes required for AI adoption.

front: What is the AI Adoption Life Cycle?
back: The structured approach to integrating AI within an organization, including phases: Exploration and Strategy (Initiation), Planning and Design, Pilot and Implementation (Execution), Evaluation and Optimization (Monitoring and Controlling), and Scaling and Institutionalization (Closure).
When AI models become less accurate over time as conditions change from when they were originally trained.
Unfair or skewed outcomes in AI models resulting from biased training data.

front: What is PMI-CPMAI™ (Certified Professional in Managing AI)?
back: A methodology and framework that bridges the gap between traditional project management and the unique needs of AI projects. It combines adaptive/agile approaches with data-centric methods, governance, and ethical oversight.

front: What are the Six Phases of PMI-CPMAI™?
back: A structured roadmap for AI projects consisting of Business Understanding, Data Understanding, Data Preparation, Model Development, Model Evaluation, and Model Operationalization.

front: What does Iterative by Design mean in PMI-CPMAI™?
back: A principle of the framework where phases loop back (e.g., Model Evaluation may reveal issues requiring more Data Preparation), reflecting the uncertainty and discovery nature of AI.

front: What is Conversational and Human Interaction pattern of AI?
back: Machines interacting naturally with humans through voice, text, or images using natural language to understand intent and context.

front: What is Recognition pattern of AI?
back: Using machine learning to identify, classify, or segment objects and elements within unstructured data (images, video, audio, text).

front: What is Predictive Analytics and Decision Support pattern of AI?
back: Utilizing machine learning to forecast future outcomes and support decision-making by analyzing past behaviors and data.

front: What is Goal-Driven Systems pattern of AI?
back: Systems that learn via trial and error (reinforcement learning) to find the optimal solution to a problem or objective.

front: What is Hyper-Personalization pattern of AI?
back: Treating each user individually by creating unique profiles to deliver tailored content, recommendations, and guidance.

front: What is Autonomous Systems pattern of AI?
back: Systems (physical or virtual) that perform tasks or interact with their environment independently with little to no human input.

front: What is Patterns and Anomalies pattern of AI?
back: Using machine learning to detect when data does not fit the norm (outliers) or to spot patterns in large data sets.
Systems that perform repeatable tasks with fixed rules in stable environments; the goal is repetition rather than intelligence.
Automation that incorporates intelligent capabilities to handle exceptions, adapt to changing conditions, and learn from experience.

front: What are the Three Ps of Intelligence?
back: The characteristics that differentiate intelligent systems from traditional automation: Perception (sensing and understanding unstructured information), Prediction (forecasting outcomes and inferring patterns), and Planning (devising strategies and optimizing approaches dynamically).

front: What is Perception in the Three Ps of Intelligence?
back: Sensing and understanding unstructured information.

front: What is Prediction in the Three Ps of Intelligence?
back: Forecasting outcomes and inferring patterns.

front: What is Planning in the Three Ps of Intelligence?
back: Devising strategies and optimizing approaches dynamically.
An intelligent system that can perceive its environment, make decisions, and take action to achieve specific objectives with some autonomy, often combining multiple AI capabilities.
An advanced strategy where AI agents continuously evaluate their own performance, identify optimization opportunities, and redesign their processes autonomously.
Aligning AI with human values to avoid harm, ensure fairness, and respect privacy.
Ensuring accountability for AI outcomes by establishing clear ownership, decision authorities, and human oversight.
Making the AI's logic, data sources, and decision-making understandable to stakeholders.
Enforcing organizational policies, standards, and regulatory compliance through robust controls and audits.
Designing systems that provide understandable reasons for their decisions so stakeholders can interpret the model's output.

front: What is Volume in Big Data Vs?
back: How much data exists.

front: What is Variety in Big Data Vs?
back: The formats of the data (structured vs. unstructured).

front: What is Velocity in Big Data Vs?
back: How fast the data updates or moves.

front: What is Veracity in Big Data Vs?
back: The reliability and consistency of the data.
Artificially generated data that reflects real-world patterns without using actual sensitive records, used to expand training sets.
When incoming data no longer matches the training data, causing model performance to degrade.
Combining Large Language Models (LLMs) with real-time information retrieval from semantic search/vector databases to ground responses in trusted data.

front: What is the role of a Project Manager/AI Project Lead?
back: Orchestrates the initiative, coordinates cross-functional teams, manages timelines, and ensures business alignment.

front: What is the role of a Data Engineer?
back: Builds and maintains data pipelines, ensures data quality/governance, and optimizes infrastructure.

front: What is the role of a Business Analyst/Domain Expert?
back: Defines requirements, translates business needs into technical specs, and ensures the solution solves real business problems.

front: What is the role of an MLOps/DevOps Engineer?
back: Connects development to production by building CI/CD pipelines, monitoring performance, and managing versioning.

front: What is the role of an Executive Sponsor?
back: Secures funding, provides strategic direction, removes barriers, and champions AI value to leadership.

front: What is the role of a Data Scientist?
back: Designs, develops, and validates custom models, choosing algorithms and performing feature engineering.

front: What is a Minimum Viable Product (MVP)?
back: A scope boundary used to deliver meaningful value quickly (often in weeks) rather than trying to solve everything at once.

front: What are Circuit Breakers in AI?
back: Safety mechanisms in agentic AI that monitor actions and automatically limit or halt operations when safety thresholds are exceeded.

front: What is a Hallucination in GenAI?
back: Plausible but false content generated by GenAI systems.
The process of transitioning validated AI models into fully integrated, production-ready systems.
A characteristic of a program or project or its environment, which is difficult to manage due to human behavior, system behavior, and ambiguity.
A state of being unclear, of not knowing what to expect or how to comprehend a situation. It is one of the three categories of complexity identified in this practice guide.
The spontaneous, unanticipated change that occurs in a program or project and which acts as a major source of uncertainty.

A lack of awareness and understanding of issues, events, path to follow, or solutions to pursue. Uncertainty may increase and amplify issues, risks, behaviors, or situations, which are internal and external to a program or project.
A common outcome of programs and projects in a complex environment. Social and political interactions and interconnectedness can create issues and/or results that are unable to be predetermined.
A cognitive bias that causes people to fixate on an early piece of data even when contradicted by more accurate subsequent data.

A process in which one applies observation, analysis, inference, context, reflective thinking, and the like, in order to reach judgments. Such judgments should be open to alternative perspectives that may not normally be otherwise considered.
A cognitive bias in which the manner that information is presented or an experiment is conducted irrationally affects the interpretation of data.
A cognitive bias in which people continue to support a clearly failing endeavor for which significant resources have already been expended. Also called sunk cost bias.
The ability to hold two contradictory thoughts about a single issue (e.g., relaxing while sprinting, loosening control amidst instability).
The natural tendency of people to underestimate probable costs or time and to overestimate probable benefits of the required efforts to complete a task.
A part of the critical thinking process, the process of considering and elucidating one’s self experiences, which is best used to apply knowledge to future activities.
A collection of various components that together can produce results not obtainable by the components alone.

One of the three categories of complexity used in this practice guide to describe a source of complexity that may arise from the interactions and interdependence of various structures through connections among their parts or components.

The interactions of connected and interdependent components, which may cause change over time and give rise to interconnected risks; emerging, unforeseeable issues; and unclear, disproportional cause-and-effect relationships.
One of the three categories of complexity used in this practice guide to describe a source of complexity that occurs from the interplay of conducts, demeanors, and attitudes of people.
The interdependence of one individual, component, or objective on other individuals, components, or objectives in a program or project.

The state of mutual reliance between two or more entities, that is, the relationship in which each program or project component is mutually dependent on others. This characteristic differs from a dependence relationship, where some components are dependent and some are not.
An identifiable element within the program or project that provides a particular function or group of related functions.
A complete, integrated set of components and/or subsystems capable of accomplishing an operational role or function.
The framework for directing and enabling an organization through its established policies, practices, and other relevant documentation.
The centralized management of one or more portfolios to achieve strategic objectives.
The application of knowledge, skills, tools, and techniques to a program to meet the program requirements and to obtain benefits and control not available by managing projects individually.

front: What is a Program Management Office?
back: A management structure that standardizes the program-related governance processes and facilitates the sharing of resources, methodologies, tools, and techniques.
The application of knowledge, skills, tools, and techniques to project activities to meet the project requirements.

front: What is a Project Management Office?
back: An organizational structure that standardizes the project-related governance processes and facilitates the sharing of resources, methodologies, tools, and techniques.
A process whereby modifications to documents, deliverables, or baselines associated with the project are identified, documented, approved, or rejected.

The process of determining if an initiative should continue or be stopped. This process usually involves analysis of the current state of the initiative. A 'go' permits the release of the solution in whole or in part. A 'no-go' either delays or disapproves the release of the solution.
An organization in which many management levels between the highest and lowest levels have been minimized.
The phenomenon in which the group's desire to achieve conformity and harmony affects the rationality of its decisions.
The phenomenon in which the interactions among members of a group cause it to take more extreme positions than its members would normally take individually.
The deliberate presentation of false information in order to achieve personal gain.

The unclear, secretive manner in which an organization conducts its business, such as making decisions, determining strategies, and setting priorities, which causes a lack of trust among stakeholders.
A spontaneous act where people come together and establish a structure or function in a purposeful manner.
The 'us vs. them' mentality that causes groups to take positions that ultimately thwart common goals and objectives.
Nongovernmental organization.
Projects, programs, subportfolios, and operations managed as a group to achieve strategic objectives.
A group of related projects, subprograms, and program activities that are managed in a coordinated way to obtain benefits not available from managing them individually.
A temporary endeavor undertaken to create a unique product, service, or result.

front: What is a Project Life Cycle?
back: The series of phases that a project passes through from its initiation to its closure.
A condition or capability that is required to be present in a product, service, or result to satisfy a contract or other formally imposed specification.
An uncertain event or condition that, if it occurs, has a positive or negative effect on one or more project objectives.
The work performed to deliver a project, service, or result with the specified features and functions.
A person or group who provides resources and support for the project, program, or portfolio and is accountable for enabling success.
An individual, group, or organization who may affect, be affected by, or perceive itself to be affected by a decision, activity, or outcome of a project.
A common type of responsibility assignment matrix that uses responsible, accountable, consult, and inform statuses to define the involvement of stakeholders in project activities.
A process that thoroughly reviews and interprets environmental data in order to develop SWOT analysis.

These activities involve commissioning a team of objective experts to assess the validity of senior management expectations regarding program or project costs and benefits. These experts could be internal or external to the organization.

A study that produces a potential recommendation to address business needs. It examines feasibility using one or more of the following variables: operational, technology/system, cost-effectiveness, and timeliness of the potential solution.
A technique for understanding the gap between current capabilities and needed capabilities. Filling the gap is what comprises a solution recommendation.

An assessment comparing available resources with those needed for a program or project. The assessment may include reviewing areas such as resources, talent, software, alliances, processes, and practices readily available to successfully complete a program or project.

These are detailed reviews by experts to consider potential risks that could ultimately cause the failure of a program or project. Risk remediation effort estimates are added to original estimates to reset the budget, scope, and schedule expectations.
A method for taking an outside view of preliminary program or project estimates in order to correct the mistakes brought on by cognitive biases.
The analysis of strengths, weaknesses, opportunities, and threats of an organization, project, or option.
The ability to adapt to a changing environment and/or situation and to adopt a flexible approach that shifts according to the situation.
Reviewing, relating, or treating entire systems and their environments, rather than separately reviewing or investigating the components of these systems.
The ability to cope with adversity and recover quickly from setbacks.

One of the three key skill sets that is considered as required for successful management of projects. Leadership skills include: negotiation, communication, motivation, problem solving, and related competencies.

front: What are Strategic and Business Management Skills?
back: One of the three key skill sets that is considered as required for successful management of projects. Strategic and business management skills include: strategy alignment, innovation, finance, marketing, and operational functions, etc.

One of the three key skill sets that is considered as required for successful management of projects. Technical project management skills include project management knowledge, product knowledge, and industry expertise.

front: What is a Key Performance Indicator (KPI)?
back: A high-level measurement meant to indicate how well an individual or group is performing a set of activities that is considered critical to the overall success of an endeavor.
A part of the resource gap analysis comparing available talents with those needed for a program or project.
A systematic procedure, technique, or process used to transfer information among project stakeholders.
A process in which the effect or output of an action is 'returned' (fed back) to modify the next action.
The overall attitude of being in a hurry to complete a solution, project, or task while overlooking potential problems or mistakes.
A plan that outlines the steps intended to be taken to reach a solution.
The effective integration of processes from multiple disciplines.
The knowledge gained during a project, which shows how project events were addressed or should be addressed in the future for the purpose of improving future performance.
Simplifying something to a point where its meaning is misrepresented or no longer accurate.
The potentially hidden connections among individual components in a hierarchical system.

A face-to-face meeting that is usually held in a location with no available chairs in order to facilitate a brief, focused meeting; however, the same outcome can be obtained by using the same technique and holding the meeting in a virtual environment.
A temporary endeavor undertaken to create a unique product, service, or result.
A group of related projects, subsidiary programs, and program activities managed in a coordinated manner to obtain benefits not available from managing them individually.
Projects, programs, subsidiary portfolios, and operations managed as a group to achieve strategic objectives.
The application of knowledge, skills, tools, and techniques to project activities to meet the project requirements.
The person assigned by the performing organization to lead the team that is responsible for achieving the project objectives.
A set of individuals who support the project manager in performing the work of the project to achieve its objectives.

front: What is a Project Life Cycle?
back: The series of phases that a project passes through from its start to its completion.
A collection of logically related project activities that culminates in the completion of one or more deliverables.
Any unique and verifiable product, result, or capability to perform a service that is required to be produced to complete a process, phase, or project.
An end result or consequence of a process or project.
The worth, importance, or usefulness of something.
The sum of the products, services, and results to be provided as a project.
A condition or capability that is necessary to be present in a product, service, or result to satisfy a business need.

front: What is a Work Breakdown Structure (WBS)?
back: A hierarchical decomposition of the total scope of work to be carried out by the project team to accomplish the project objectives and create the required deliverables.
The approved version of a work product that can be changed only through formal change control procedures and is used as a basis for comparison to actual results.
A significant point or event in a project, program, or portfolio.
A model that presents linked activities with planned dates, durations, milestones, and resources.
A description of a project or product attribute and how to measure it.

front: What is a Key Performance Indicator (KPI)?
back: A set of quantifiable measures used to evaluate the success of an organization, employee, etc., in meeting objectives for performance.
The measure of work performed expressed in terms of the budget authorized for that work.
A measure of a team's productivity rate at which the deliverables are produced, validated, and accepted within a given time interval.
The amount of time whereby a successor activity will be delayed with respect to a predecessor activity.
The amount of time whereby a successor activity can be advanced with respect to a predecessor activity.
A quantifiable deviation, departure, or divergence away from a known baseline or expected value.
A template, document, output, or project deliverable.
A development approach in which the requirements are subject to a high level of uncertainty and volatility and are likely to change throughout the project.
A development approach in which the project scope, time, and cost are determined in the early phases of the life cycle.
A combination of two or more agile and non-agile elements, having a non-agile end result.
The deliberate adaptation of the project management approach, governance, and processes to make them more suitable for the given environment and the work at hand.
An informal, general explanation of a software feature written from the perspective of the end user.
A large user story that cannot be delivered as defined within a single iteration or is large enough that it can be split into smaller user stories.
An ordered list of work to be done.
An individual, group, or organization that may affect, be affected by, or perceive itself to be affected by a decision, activity, or outcome of a project, program, or portfolio.
A person or group who provides resources and support for the project, program, or portfolio and is accountable for enabling success.
The framework for directing and enabling an organization through its established policies, practices, and other relevant documentation.
A process whereby modifications to documents, deliverables, or baselines associated with the project are identified, documented, approved, or rejected.

front: What is a Change Control Board (CCB)?
back: A formally chartered group responsible for reviewing, evaluating, approving, delaying, or rejecting changes to the project, and for recording and communicating such decisions.
An uncertain event or condition that, if it occurs, has a positive or negative effect on one or more project objectives.
A risk that would have a negative effect on one or more project objectives.
A risk that would have a positive effect on one or more project objectives.
A current condition or situation that may have an impact on the project objectives.
A factor in the planning process that is considered to be true, real, or certain, without proof or demonstration.
A limiting factor that affects the execution of a project, program, portfolio, or process.
A visible, physical display that provides information to the rest of the organization, enabling up-to-the-minute knowledge sharing without having to disturb the team.
A graphic representation of the work remaining in a timebox or the work completed toward the release of a product or project deliverable.
A set of charts and graphs showing progress or performance against important measures of the project.

A bar chart of schedule information where activities are listed on the vertical axis, dates are shown on the horizontal axis, and activity durations are shown as horizontal bars placed according to start and finish dates.
A set of conditions that are met before deliverables are accepted.
The act of listening completely with all senses so as to pick up all of the information that is being communicated.
A distinct, scheduled portion of work performed during the course of a project.
A type of process model that visually shows the complex flow of use cases.
People or other systems that interact with a solution.

front: What is an Actual Acceptance Result?
back: Contains the pass/fail results from comparing test results against the acceptance criteria.
The skill of being flexible and willing to adjust how one performs work or goes about approaching a situation as change and new information is encountered.

front: What is an Adaptive Life Cycle?
back: A project life cycle that is iterative and incremental.
A technique that allows large numbers of ideas to be classified into groups for review and analysis.
An example of an adaptive project life cycle.
A technique for estimating the duration or cost of an activity or a project using historical data from a similar activity or project.
The process of examining, breaking down, and synthesizing information to further understand, complete, and improve it.

Describes how analysis will be performed; how to verify, validate, and prioritize requirements and other product information; how risks will be identified and analyzed; how design options will be assessed; and what techniques and templates are expected to be used to perform analysis.

front: What is the Analysis Knowledge Area?
back: Includes the processes for examining, breaking down, synthesizing, and clarifying information to further understand it, complete it, and improve it.
A visual representation of product information.
A person on the product team who performs business analysis.

A set of skills in business analysis that are used to process information of various types and at various levels of detail for the purpose of determining the relevant information from the irrelevant, drawing conclusions, building models, formulating decisions, and specifying requirements.
A requirement that is verified and validated and has been deemed an accurate reflection of what the product development team should build.
A method to describe an organization by mapping its essential characteristics, such as people, locations, processes, applications, data, and technology.
Analysis and design documentation that has been updated to correspond to a released product.
The process of synthesizing well-researched and analyzed information to support the selection of the best portfolio components, programs, or projects to address the business goals and objectives.

front: What is Assess Business Analysis Performance?
back: The process of considering the effectiveness of the business analysis practices in use across the organization, typically in the context of considering the ongoing deliverables and results of a portfolio component, program, or project.

The process of examining the current environment under analysis to understand important factors that are internal or external to the organization, which may be the cause or reason for a problem or opportunity.

front: What is Assess Product Design Options?
back: The process of identifying, analyzing, and comparing solution design options based on the business goals and objectives, expected costs of implementation, feasibility, and associated risks and using the results of this assessment to provide recommendations regarding the design options presented.

front: What is Assessment of Business Value?
back: The result of comparing expected business value for a solution against actual value that has been realized.
A factor in the planning process that is considered to be true, real, or certain, without proof or demonstration.
An approach for making decisions where one individual makes the decision for the group.
Tool-supported validation used after changes are made to a software system to ensure those changes did not unintentionally alter the system in some other way.
A foundational part of a story map representing the minimum set of capabilities that absolutely are required to be in the first release for the solution to serve its purpose.
A listing of product requirements and deliverables to be completed, often written as user stories, and prioritized by the business to manage and organize the project's work.
A process used on agile projects where the product team works with the product owner to gain more in-depth understanding about the user stories in the backlog list.
A circumstance in a burndown chart where the remaining quantity of what is being tracked increases over time.
A technique that establishes the relationship of a requirement to the scope, business goals, or business objectives from which it originated.
The approved version of a work product that can be changed using formal change control procedures and is used as the basis for comparison to actual results.
An approach that suggests the team begins with understanding how the user will use a product (its behavior), writes tests for that behavior, and then constructs solutions against the tests.

The comparison of actual or planned practices, such as processes and operations, to those of comparable organizations to identify best practices, generate ideas for improvement, and provide a basis for measuring performance.
The gains and assets realized by the organization and other stakeholders as the result of outcomes delivered by the solution.
A method of estimating duration or cost by aggregating the estimates of the lower-level components of the work breakdown structure (WBS).

In business analysis, brainstorming is an elicitation technique that is performed in a group setting and led by a facilitator to engage stakeholders to quickly identify a list of ideas for a specific topic in a relatively short time period.
A graphical representation that counts the remaining quantity of some trackable aspect over time.

In business analysis, the area of an organization that is experiencing a problem or possessing an opportunity along with the desire and interest in and willingness to sponsor changes to address the need.
The skill of applying business and industry knowledge with decision-making capabilities to make sound decisions.
The set of activities performed to support delivery of solutions that align to business objectives and provide continuous value to the organization.

front: What is a Business Analysis Approach?
back: A description of how business analysis processes will be conducted for a portfolio component, program, or project.

front: What is a Business Analysis Center of Excellence?
back: An organizational structure created whereby business analysts are managed centrally or are provided mentorship centrally for the purpose of improving the business analysis discipline across the organization.

Any unique and verifiable result, produced throughout the course of performing business analysis activities, which is provided to team members and stakeholders to perform future work, decision making, or complete a process, phase, or initiative.
The set of business analysis information produced as an output of the business analysis work conducted on a portfolio, program, or project.

front: What is a Business Analysis Methodology?
back: A system of practices, techniques, tools, procedures, and rules used by those who work in the business analysis discipline.

front: What is a Business Analysis Organizational Standard?
back: Part of organizational process assets, these standards may include expectations for how business analysis is conducted and which tools are used to support business analysis efforts.

front: What is Business Analysis Performance Assessment?
back: An evaluation of what has been learned about the effectiveness of the business analysis processes and of the business analysis techniques that have been used.

front: What are Business Analysis Performance Metrics?
back: A qualitative or quantitative measure of or inference about the effectiveness of business analysis practices.

front: What is a Business Analysis Plan?
back: A summary of the choices and process decisions made in the business analysis approaches, including the identification of the business analysis tasks that will be performed, the deliverables that will be produced, and the roles required to perform the work.
The need to adjust which business analysis activities should be performed for projects of varying characteristics.
Any resource who is performing the work of business analysis.
A collection of the business functions, organizational structures, and locations, and processes of an organization, including documents and depictions of those elements.

front: What is a Business Architecture Technique?
back: An organizational framework available to model business architecture, providing different approaches for analyzing various aspects of the business.
A technique used to analyze performance in terms of processes, people skills, and other resources used by an organization to perform its work.
A documented economic feasibility study used to establish validity of the benefits to be delivered by a portfolio component, program, or project.

front: What is a Business Data Object?
back: For business analysis, a business data object is a grouping of facts that together describe a person, place, thing, or concept of interest to a business.
A broad-based translation of a corporate goal into what the business specifically is seeking to achieve.
The impetus for a change in an organization based on an existing problem or opportunity.
Measurable representation of the goals the business is seeking to achieve.

front: What is a Business Objectives Model?
back: A business analysis model that relates the business problems, business objectives, and top-level features.

A requirement that describes a higher-level need of the organization, such as a business issue or opportunity, the rationale for why an initiative is being undertaken, and a measurable representation of a goal the business is seeking to achieve.
A constraint about how the organization wants to operate.

front: What is a Business Rules Catalog?
back: A business analysis model that details all of the business rules and their related attributes.
The net quantifiable benefit derived from a business endeavor.
A type of collaborative game used to enable a group of stakeholders to agree on prioritization by giving each stakeholder an amount of pretend money to buy their choice of features.
The ability to add value or achieve objectives in an organization through a function, process, service, or other proficiency.
A collection of an organization's capabilities, organized into manageable pieces, similar to business architecture.
A table that displays the capabilities needed to solve a problem or seize an opportunity.
An indication of the quantity of one business data object which is associated with a related business data object.

front: What is Cause and Effect Diagram?
back: A decomposition technique that helps trace an undesirable effect back to its root cause.
A person who acts as a catalyst for organizational innovation possessing the vision to recognize where and when a change is needed and influencing to bring the change to fruition.
A process whereby modifications to documents, deliverables, or baselines associated with the project are identified, documented, approved, or rejected.

front: What is a Change Control Board (CCB)?
back: A formally chartered group responsible for reviewing, evaluating, approving, delaying, or rejecting changes to the project, and for recording and communicating such decisions.
Manual or automated tools to assist with change and/or configuration management.
A formal proposal to modify a document, deliverable, or baseline.
A collection of elicitation techniques that foster collaboration, innovation, and creativity to achieve the goal of the elicitation activity.

front: What is a Communication and Collaboration Tool?
back: A category of tools used in business analysis to effectively work with stakeholders and share and manage information.
A collection of skills in business analysis utilized to provide, receive, or elicit information from various sources.

front: What is a Communications Management Plan?
back: A component of the project, program, or portfolio management plan that describes how, when, and by whom information will be administered and disseminated.
Selecting the appropriate method and style of communication to use in a given situation based on factors such as audience and available communication methods.
A technique for obtaining and analyzing information about an organization's external environment.

front: What is Conduct Business Analysis Planning?
back: The process performed to obtain shared agreement regarding the business analysis activities the team will be performing and the assignment of roles, responsibilities, and skill sets for the tasks required to successfully complete the business analysis work.
