front: What is Conceptual and Detailed Thinking?
back: The ability to move between analyzing at a high-level view of a problem space and a specific detail or set of details that comprise one aspect of the problem space.
The process of applying various elicitation techniques to draw out information from stakeholders and other sources.

The process of researching and analyzing quantitative and qualitative information about the individuals, groups, or organizations that may impact, are impacted, or are perceived to be impacted by the area under assessment.
A collection of formal documented processes, templates, and documentation used to apply governance to changes to the solution, or subcomponent being developed.
The criteria established for what constitutes compliance with configuration management procedures and their associated systems and tools.

front: What is a Configuration Management System (CMS)?
back: A collection of procedures used to track project artifacts and monitor and control changes to these artifacts.
The process of performing follow-up activities on the elicitation results, determining an appropriate level of formality to use, reviewing with stakeholders, and comparing to historical information.
Consist of the business analysis information obtained from completed elicitation activities signifying the product team has reached a common understanding.
A factor that limits the options for managing a project, program, portfolio, or process.
A visual depiction of the product scope showing a business system (process, equipment, computer system, etc.) and how people and other systems (actors) interact with it.
A designated event scheduled for the conclusion of a segment of work in order to evaluate progress against plans and the project charter and business case.
A financial analysis tool used to determine the benefits provided by a portfolio component, program, or project against its costs.
The high-level economic feasibility of a potential portfolio component, program, or project, taking into account both financial benefits and costs.

front: What is Create and Analyze Models?
back: The process of creating structured representations, such as diagrams, tables, or structured text, of any product information, to facilitate further analysis.
The ability to resolve a problem or set of problems by exploring multiple and different solutions to arrive at an improved future result.
A team where each team member can play more than one role.
CRUD, defined as (C) create, (R) read, (U) update, and (D) delete, represents the operations that can be applied to data or objects.
Being conscious of the cultural norms and values of others.
An understanding of the current mode of operations, or the as-is state of the organization.
Internal or external stakeholders who benefit from the development of a solution.
A business analysis model that catalogs the attributes of specific data objects.

front: What is a Data Flow Diagram?
back: A business analysis model that combines processes, systems, and data to show how data flows through a solution.
A visual representation of the business data objects of interest to a business and the relationships between them.
A source of business information, often represented visually on a data flow diagram.

front: What is Day in the Life Testing (DITL)?
back: A semiformal activity conducted by someone with in-depth business knowledge to validate or evaluate whether a solution provides the functionality for a typical day of usage by a role that interacts with the solution.
An approach for making group decisions based upon general agreement for the decision by the group.
An approach for making decisions where the decision is made by the sponsor, with or without input from a group.

front: What is Decision by Weighted Analysis?
back: An approach for making decisions using decision criteria identified by and assigned relative weights by those involved in making the decision.
The ability to weigh the benefits and drawbacks associated with a set of options, choose among various options, and articulate the rationale for the choice.
A business analysis model that helps identify business rules associated with any complex branching logic in a solution by considering all combinations of choices.
A business analysis model that shows business rules associated with any complex branching logic in a solution.

A model that is used to divide and subdivide a high-level concept into lower-level concepts, for example dividing the project scope and project deliverables into smaller, more manageable parts for the purpose of analysis.
An acronym that describes the characteristics that a product backlog needs to demonstrate to be considered well refined: detailed appropriately, estimated, emergent, and prioritized.
The process of obtaining agreement as to what would constitute proof that one or more aspects of a solution have been developed successfully.

front: What is Define and Elaborate Requirements?
back: The process of refining and documenting requirements and other types of product information at the appropriate level of detail, format, and level of formality required for various audiences.

front: What is the Defining and Aligning Process Group?
back: The business analysis processes performed to investigate and evaluate the viability of initiating a new product or changes to or retirement of an existing product as well as defining scope and aligning products, portfolios, programs, and projects to the overall organizational strategy.
A series of conditions that the entire team agrees to complete before an item is considered sufficiently developed to be accepted by the business stakeholders.
A series of conditions that the entire team agrees to complete before a user story is considered sufficiently understood for work to begin to construct it.
Any unique and verifiable product, result, or capability to perform a service that is produced to complete a process, phase, or project.
A consensus-building method that consolidates anonymous input from subject matter experts (SMEs) using rounds of voting.
A logical relationship that exists between two or more entities.
A technique that is used to discover dependent relationships.
A representation of how a solution could be constructed.
An approach that uses solution-based thinking rather than problem-based thinking to produce creative solutions to achieve goals.
A category of tools used in a personal workspace, for example on a laptop or on a personal device, for the purpose of aiding organization and productivity.

The process of thinking ahead about how analysis will be performed including what will be analyzed, which models will be most beneficial to produce, and how requirements and other product information will be verified, validated, and prioritized.

The process of thinking through how elicitation activities will be conducted, which stakeholders will be involved, which elicitation techniques may be used, and the order in which the elicitation activities will be best performed.
The process of determining gaps in existing capabilities and a set of proposed changes necessary to attain a desired future state that addresses the problem or opportunity under analysis.

front: What is Determine Solution Evaluation Approach?
back: The process of determining what aspects of the organization and/or solution will be evaluated, how performance will be measured, when performance will be measured, and by whom.

front: What is Determine Stakeholder Engagement and Communication Approach?
back: The process of developing appropriate methods to effectively engage and communicate with stakeholders throughout the product life cycle, based on the analysis of their needs, interests, and roles within the business analysis process.
original_term: Determine Stakeholder Engagement and Communication Approach

front: What is Determine Traceability and Monitoring Approach?
back: The process of considering how traceability will be performed on the portfolio, program, project, or product, and defining how requirement changes will be managed.

front: What is Determine Viable Options and Provide Recommendation?
back: The process of applying various analysis techniques to examine possible solutions for meeting the business goals and objectives and to determine which of the options is considered the best possible one for the organization to pursue.
original_term: Determine Viable Options and Provide Recommendation

back: A concept or an organizational unit that promotes collaboration between development, quality control, and operations to support rapidly releasing a solution by operationalizing it in small segments.
A business analysis model that dissects a user interface mockup into its display and behavior requirements at the page element level.
An elicitation technique used to analyze existing documentation to identify relevant product information.
A discipline or area of study.
A scope model that shows the relevant systems, the relationships between systems, and optionally any data objects passed between them.
A term used on adaptive projects to describe the process of detailing product information over time.
The activity of drawing out information from stakeholders and other sources.

An informal device used by a business analyst to prepare for elicitation work, defining important information such as how elicitation will be performed, what information to elicit, and when to conduct the activities.

front: What is the Elicitation Knowledge Area?
back: The processes for planning and preparing for elicitation, conducting elicitation and confirming elicitation results to obtain information from sources.
The items that are created to increase the probability of meeting elicitation activity objectives, while maximizing time spent with elicitation participants.
The business analysis information obtained from a completed elicitation activity.
A session or activity conducted to obtain information from participants.
A process where stakeholders discover their requirements as portions of the solution are delivered over time.

front: What is Enterprise and Organizational Knowledge?
back: An understanding and familiarity with the way a specific business is organized and operates, from both a high-level and tactical standpoint.
A collection of the business and technology components needed to operate an enterprise.
Conditions, not under the immediate control of the team, that influence, constrain, or direct the project, program, or portfolio.

front: What is an Entity Relationship Diagram (ERD)?
back: A business analysis model that shows the business data objects or pieces of information of interest and the relationships between those objects, including the cardinality of those relationships.
A large user story that is too big to construct in an iteration.

front: What is Establish Relationships and Dependencies?
back: The process of tracing or setting linkages between and among requirements and other product information.
A quantitative assessment of the likely amount or outcome of a variable, such as costs, resources, effort, or durations.
A collaborative relative estimation technique in which there is an agreed-upon scale used for the relative estimates.
Acting with integrity and displaying behavior that is honest.

front: What is Evaluate Acceptance Results and Address Defects?
back: The process of deciding what to do with the results from a comparison of the defined acceptance criteria against the solution.
original_term: Evaluate Acceptance Results and Address Defects

back: The process of evaluating a solution to determine whether the implemented solution or solution component is delivering the business value as intended.

The comparison between the acceptance criteria and the actual results, along with the root cause for variances or defects, the analysis of the cost to address the defect, and the business impact of addressing it or accepting it.
For business analysis, an action of interest to a business, for which there is often a planned response.
A scope model that describes any external events that trigger solution behavior.
A prototype that is the actual finished solution in process.

front: What is the Executing Process Group?
back: The business analysis processes performed to elicit, analyze, model, define, verify, validate, prioritize, and approve all types of product information.
Judgment based upon expertise in an application area, Knowledge Area, discipline, industry, etc., as appropriate for the activity being performed.
An unscripted, free-form validation or evaluation activity conducted by someone with in-depth business or testing knowledge to validate the solution and discover product errors.
A source or receiver of business information that is outside of the scope of the system under study.
An action that is triggered outside of the boundary of the system under study where there is an expectation that the planned response to that action is within scope.

front: What is Facilitate Product Roadmap Development?
back: The process of supporting the development of a product roadmap that outlines, at a high level, which aspects of a product are planned for delivery over a course of the portfolio, program, or one or more project iterations or releases.
Structured meetings led by a skilled, neutral facilitator and a carefully selected group of stakeholders to collaborate and work toward a stated objective.
The collection of activities involved in directing and coordinating work among groups of people.
A study that produces a potential recommendation to address business needs, examining feasibility using variables such as operational, technology, cost-effectiveness, and timeliness.
The summarized outcomes obtained from the completion of the feasibility analysis.
A set of related requirements typically described in short phrases.
A framework and set of principles used to improve and expedite how a product team develops and analyzes product requirements.
A scope model that visually represents all the features of a solution arranged in a tree or hierarchical structure.
A numeric sequence in which each succeeding number is the sum of the two previous numbers, such as 0, 1, 1, 2, 3, 5, 8, 13, 21 etc.
A version of a cause-and-effect diagram that depicts a problem and its root causes in a visual manner.
A technique for conducting root cause analysis suggesting anyone trying to understand a problem needs to ask why it is occurring up to five times to thoroughly understand its causes.
An elicitation technique that brings together prequalified stakeholders and subject matter experts to learn about their expectations and attitudes about a proposed product, service, or result.
A decision-making technique that can be used to help product teams analyze whether there is sufficient support to pursue a change.
For business analysis, the degree of conformance to a precise detailed format of documentation and to following established procedures which a group or organization may require.
A technique that establishes the relationship of a requirement to the design or code which implements it or to tests which verify that it has been satisfied.
A requirement that describes the behavior of a product.
Desired mode of operations once a solution is implemented.
A technique for understanding the gap between current capabilities and needed capabilities.
In business analysis, a glossary is used to list terms, definitions, and acronyms.
Something that an organization seeks to accomplish or achieve.
A business analysis model that shows the stakeholder goals for a solution with any supporting or conflicting goal relationships indicated.
An expectation regarding acceptable behavior for team members.
A market analysis quadrant diagram used to qualitatively analyze products or product lines.
A high-quality reproduction of something that is identical to, or indistinguishable from, the thing or functionality or concept which it replicates.
A method of prototyping that creates a functioning representation of the final finished solution to the user.

front: What is Identify and Analyze Product Risks?
back: The process of uncovering and examining assumptions and uncertainties that could positively or negatively affect success in the definition, development, and the expected results of the solution.

front: What is Identify Problem or Opportunity?
back: The process of identifying the problem to be solved or the opportunity to be pursued.
The process of identifying the individuals, groups, or organizations that may impact, are impacted, or are perceived to be impacted by the area under assessment.
A technique for evaluating a change in relation to how it will affect other requirements, the product, the program, and the project.

Expertise in and familiarity with the industry in which an organization is participating and includes knowledge about an organization's competitors, industry trends and challenges, applicable business models, etc.

front: What is the Initiating Process Group?
back: The business analysis processes performed to define the portfolio, program, or project objectives and apply resources to a portfolio component, program, project, or project phase.
Any item that is required by a process before that process proceeds.

In business analysis, a formal and rigorous form of review in which practitioners close to the work (usually other business analysts, developers, test team members, or quality team members) examine the work for completeness, consistency, and conformance to internal and external standards, usually by means of a checklist.
A lightweight version of a traceability matrix that is used to figure out whether requirements are sufficiently detailed or if any entities are missing.
A model that shows how the solution interacts with other systems and users.

front: What is Internal Rate of Return (IRR)?
back: The projected annual yield of an investment, incorporating both initial and ongoing costs into an estimated percentage growth rate a given project is expected to have.
Skills used to establish and maintain relationships with other people.
A special type of cause-and-effect diagram that depicts related causes and effects for a given situation.
A formal or informal approach to elicit information from stakeholders by asking questions and documenting the responses provided by the interviewees.
Using instinct to drive decision making.

The characteristics that user stories need to demonstrate to be considered 'good' and 'ready' for development in adaptive approaches (independent, negotiable, valuable, estimable, small, and testable).
A version of a cause-and-effect diagram that depicts a problem and its root causes in a visual manner.
A current condition or situation that may have an impact on the project objectives.
On adaptive projects, an iteration is a development cycle that begins with an iteration planning session and ends with retrospectives.
On adaptive projects, iteration 0 is the iteration where the initial planning for all iterations occur.
The subset of the product backlog that was chosen during iteration planning to be delivered during a specific iteration.
In adaptive approaches, iteration planning or sprint planning is the activity to identify the subset of work items that the product development team will work on for the current iteration or sprint.

A project life cycle where the project scope is generally determined early in the project life cycle, but time and cost estimates are routinely modified as the project team's understanding of the product increases.
A technique used to identify job requirements and the competencies needed to perform effectively in a specific job.
An adaptive life cycle in which items are pulled from a backlog and started when other product backlog items are completed.
A tool used within the continuous improvement method of Kanban to visually depict workflow and capacity and assist team members in seeing the work that is planned, in process, or completed.
A technique used to model and analyze product features by considering the features from the viewpoint of the customer.

front: What is a Key Performance Indicator (KPI)?
back: Metrics usually defined by an organization's executives that are used to evaluate an organization's progress toward meeting the targets or end-states stated in their objectives or goals.

A stakeholder who is identified as having a significant stake in a portfolio, program, or project, and who can hold key responsibilities such as approving requirements or approving changes to product scope.
A set of processes associated with a particular function.
The actions and efforts of a group of people toward a common goal, which enables them to work as a team.
A category of skills in business analysis consisting of the skills to direct a group of people to work together toward a common goal.
A person who possesses a willingness to learn new skills, discover improved ways of doing things, and staying curious.
The knowledge gained during a project, which shows how project events were addressed or should be addressed in the future for the purpose of improving future performance.
Having familiarity with the different frameworks that a given industry uses to identify phases of product development, from envisioning and planning through construction, iteration, and end-of-life.
A dependency between two activities or between an activity and a milestone.
Conceptual, business, or theoretical entities that represent how people think about subdividing parts of a solution.
A rough representation of something that enables someone to better understand the thing or functionality or concept which it illustrates.
A method of prototyping that provides fixed sketches, diagrams, and notes to provide a visual representation of what a user interface will look like.
A method of prototyping or creating a mockup of web pages or screens that is sometimes used to demonstrate navigation.
The ease with which a product can be kept in good working order, including the ability to make appropriate modifications.

front: What is Manage Changes to Requirements and Other Product Information?
back: The process of examining changes or defects that arise during a project by understanding the value and impact of the changes.
original_term: Manage Changes to Requirements and Other Product Information

front: What is Manage Stakeholder Engagement and Communication?
back: The process of fostering appropriate involvement in business analysis processes, keeping stakeholders appropriately informed about ongoing business analysis efforts, and sharing product information with stakeholders as it evolves.

A technique used to obtain and analyze market characteristics and conditions for the market area an organization is operating in and overlaying this information with an organization's own plans and projections for growth.

A standard that describes typical behaviors for a practice or set of practices as a series of levels, where each level represents increased levels of competence, independence, and perhaps even wisdom.
The quantity of some element at a point in time or during a specific time duration.
A system of practices, techniques, tools, procedures, and rules used by those who work in a discipline.
A set of quantifiable measures used to evaluate a solution or business.
A prioritization mechanism in which the smallest piece of functionality that still delivers value to the customer is identified.

front: What is a Minimum Viable Product (MVP)?
back: A prioritization mechanism to define the scope of the first release of a solution to customers by identifying the fewest number of features or requirements that would constitute a solution that the customer would obtain value from.
A visual representation of information, both abstract and specific, which operates under a set of guidelines to efficiently arrange and convey a lot of information in an efficient manner.
A technique that uses the collection of models together to further identify gaps, inconsistencies, or redundancies in product information.
A set of models and their syntax.
A category of tools used in business analysis to develop visual representations of information for the purpose of communicating and analyzing information in a clear, efficient manner.
The process of collecting performance data, producing performance measures, and reporting and disseminating performance information.

front: What is the Monitoring and Controlling Process Group?
back: The processes performed on an ongoing basis to assess the impact of proposed product changes within a portfolio, program, or project to assess business analysis performance and to promote ongoing communication and engagement with stakeholders.
A technique used for establishing requirement priorities where participants divide the requirements into four categories of must haves, should haves, could haves, and won't haves.
Being capable of performing more than one task at a time.
A technique used to facilitate decision making among a group of stakeholders.
A story.

front: What is the Needs Assessment Knowledge Area?
back: Includes the processes for analyzing current business problems or opportunities to understand what is necessary to attain the desired future state.
The process and activities used to resolve disputes through consultations between involved parties.
The future value of expected benefits expressed in the value those benefits have at the time of investment.
A requirement that expresses an environmental condition or quality required for the product to be effective.
The ability to use unspoken communication methods to interact with stakeholders.
Within the context of use case analysis, the normal flow is the set of steps that are followed through the use case scenario when everything goes as planned or expected.
The ability of being able to reason with numbers and other mathematical concepts and to apply these in a range of contexts and to solve a variety of problems.
Something toward which work is to be directed, a strategic position to be attained, a purpose to be achieved, a result to be obtained, a product to be produced, or a service to be performed.

Listening to and encouraging the presentation of multiple perspectives on a given issue, weighing the merits of each perspective dispassionately and without bias, and avoiding taking sides prematurely.

An elicitation technique that provides a direct way of obtaining information about how a process is performed or a product is used by viewing individuals in their own environment performing their jobs or tasks and carrying out processes.

front: What is Obtain Solution Acceptance for Release?
back: The process of facilitating a decision on whether to release a partial or full solution into production and eventually to an operational team, as well as transitioning knowledge and existing information about the product, its risks, known issues, and any workarounds that may have arisen in response to those issues.
A technique that can be used to model relationships between different aspects of a subject.
The extent to which a proposed solution meets operational needs and requirements related to a specific situation.
A risk that would have a positive effect on one or more project objectives.
A study of the major facets of a potential opportunity to determine the viability of successfully launching a new solution.
A model that depicts the reporting structure within an organization or within a part of an organization.
Complementary approaches for improving the performance of an organization by catalyzing improvements in the actions of and interactions between individuals or teams.
A broad-based translation of a corporate goal into an expression that is actionable and measurable.
An accomplishment that an organization wants to achieve to help enable a goal.
Plans, processes, policies, procedures, and knowledge bases specific to and used by the performing organization.
A system composed of organizational components that are identifiable elements within an organization and provide a particular function or group of related functions.
An end result or consequence of a process or actions.
A product, result, or service generated by a process.
A histogram, ordered by frequency of occurrence, that shows how many results were generated by each identified cause.
One who participates in a group activity, such as focus groups or facilitated workshops.
The time needed to recover an investment, usually in months or years.
An informal peer review completed by one or multiple peers simultaneously to look over the materials.
Involves a review process where a coworker examines work completed by a business analyst.
A quantified output of a product.

A complementary grouping of related areas of activity or function that uniquely characterize and differentiate the activities within it from the others within the full scope of some overall area of study.
Integrated scope, schedule, and cost baselines used for comparison to manage, measure, and control project execution.
An archetype user representing a set of similar end users described with their goals, motivations, and representative personal characteristics.
A technique that can be used to analyze a class of users or process workers to understand their needs or solution design and behavior requirements.
The efforts and actions taken to improve skills and knowledge.
In business analysis, the set of skills and attributes that identify the personal qualities of an individual and enable them to build credibility with others.
Entities such as systems or software that exist as part of a solution that can be installed, implemented, touched, or seen.
Decisions regarding how business analysis is to be conducted.

front: What is the Planning Process Group?
back: The business analysis processes performed to determine an optimal approach for performing business analysis activities, including how they are adapted for the chosen project life cycle, and to analyze the internal and external stakeholders who will interact and influence the overall definition of the solution.
A structured pattern of actions adopted by an organization such that the organization's policy can be explained as a set of basic principles that govern the organization's conduct.
Being conscious of the human dynamics within a work environment as they relate to organizational levels, hierarchy, and the way power is distributed throughout.
Projects, programs, subsidiary portfolios, and operations managed as a group to achieve strategic objectives.
A document issued by a sponsor that authorizes and specifies the portfolio structure and links the portfolio to the organization's strategic objectives.
A discrete element of a portfolio that is a program, project, or other work.
The centralized management of one or more portfolios to achieve strategic objectives.
Portfolio activities related to actively identifying, monitoring, analyzing, accepting, mitigating, avoiding, or retiring portfolio risk.
The manner in which work is performed, which is less formal than a methodology, is not required, and is typically based on preferences or recommended conventions or approaches.
A form of project life cycle in which the project scope, time, and cost are determined in the early phases of the life cycle.
The process of organizing and scheduling resources and preparing necessary materials for an individual elicitation activity.

front: What is Prepare for Transition to Future State?
back: The process of determining whether the organization is ready for a transition and how the organization will move from the current to the future state to integrate the solution or partial solution into the organization's operations.
original_term: Prepare for Transition to Future State

back: Testing a solution in a separate environment that is identical or nearly identical to the production environment, so that adverse interactions with other products in the production environment can be observed and addressed before the solution is released to production.

front: What is Prioritize Requirements and Other Product Information?
back: The process of understanding how individual pieces of product information achieve stakeholder objectives, and using that information, along with other agreed-upon prioritization factors, to facilitate ranking of the work.
original_term: Prioritize Requirements and Other Product Information

back: Different methods used to prioritize portfolio components, programs, projects, requirements, features, or any other product information.

front: What are Prioritized Requirements and Other Product Information?
back: A representation of the requirements and other product information that stakeholders agree are most important to address first to achieve the business goals and objectives.
original_term: Prioritized Requirements and Other Product Information

back: An internal or external environmental area of an organization that is causing detriment to the organization.

The ability to analyze an issue or difficult situation by performing sufficient analysis to understand the problem, identify possible options to address the situation, select and implement an effective solution, and monitor the outcomes to ensure the problem was sufficiently addressed.
An established method of accomplishing a consistent performance or result.
A systematic series of activities directed toward causing an end result such that one or more inputs will be acted upon to create one or more outputs.
A business analysis model that visually shows the steps taken in a process by a human user as it interacts with a solution.
The stakeholder who physically works with or within the business process that is under analysis or the user who works specifically with a system that is part of the business process.
An artifact that is produced, is quantifiable, and can be either an end item in itself or a component item.

front: What is a Product Backlog Item?
back: A work item or item of value to the customer that has to be prioritized and completed.
An elicitation technique that uses game play to focus on the features of a product that are important to the customer.
Any documentation produced to support business analysis processes.

All elements needed to produce a solution successfully, which can include business, stakeholder, solution or transition requirements, models, assumptions, dependencies, constraints, issues, and risks.

Having an understanding about the different product offerings an organization provides to its customers, the strengths and weaknesses of each compared against competitor offerings, and the opportunities and threats existing for those offerings.
The series of phases that represent the evolution of a product, from concept through delivery, growth, maturity, and to retirement.
An individual responsible for achieving customer and market success for a product.
An individual with decision-making authority for prioritizing what to include or exclude from one or more specific products.

front: What is a Product Portfolio Matrix?
back: A market analysis quadrant diagram that is used to qualitatively analyze products or product lines.
The process of determining whether or not a delivered product meets or exceeds acceptance criteria.
Something that can be met by a solution and addresses a need of a business, person, or group of people.
An uncertainty that can affect success in definition, development, and expected results of the product or solution.
The consolidated results from identifying and analyzing product risks.
A high-level view of the features and functionality to include in a product, along with the sequence in which they will be built or delivered.
The features and functions that characterize a product, service, or result.
An individual, group, or organization that may affect, be affected by, or perceive to be affected by the solution.
An explanation of the product, intended customers, and how needs will be met.
A category of techniques a product team can use to obtain a shared understanding about the product and set the high-level direction for its development.
The ability to communicate complex ideas clearly and succinctly using written language and demonstrating proficiency in the mechanics of writing and in the selection of the appropriate writing style.
Related projects, subsidiary programs, and program activities managed in a coordinated manner to obtain benefits not available from managing them individually.
A document issued by a sponsor that authorizes the program management team to use organizational resources to execute the program and links the program to the organization's strategic objectives.
The application of knowledge, skills, and principles to a program to achieve the program objectives and to obtain benefits and control not available by managing program components individually.
Program activities related to actively identifying, monitoring, analyzing, accepting, mitigating, avoiding, or retiring program risk.
A temporary endeavor undertaken to create a unique product, service, or result.
An outcome of an action, behavior, or product that provides value to the sponsoring organization as well as to the intended beneficiaries of the project.

A document issued by the project initiator or sponsor that formally authorizes the existence of a project and provides the project manager with the authority to apply organizational resources to project activities.
The series of phases that a project passes through from its start to its completion.
The application of knowledge, skills, tools, and techniques to project activities to meet the project requirements.
The document that describes how the project will be executed, monitored and controlled, and closed.
The person assigned by the performing organization to lead the team that is responsible for achieving the project objectives.
A collection of logically related project activities that culminates in the completion of one or more deliverables.
The processes of conducting risk management planning, identification, analysis, response planning, response implementation, and monitoring risk on a project.
An output of a schedule model that presents linked activities with planned dates, durations, milestones, and resources.
The work performed to deliver a product, service, or result with the specified features and functions.
A set of individuals who support the project manager in performing the work of the project to achieve its objectives.
A representation of the expected solution before it is built.
A method of obtaining early feedback on requirements by providing a working model of the expected solution before actually building it.

front: What is a Purpose Alignment Model?
back: A technique that can be used to help facilitate discussions about priorities by placing product features on a matrix according to their criticality and market differentiation.
The process of examining the effectiveness of quality control.
A written set of questions designed to quickly accumulate information from a large number of respondents.
A common type of responsibility assignment matrix that uses responsible, accountable, consult, and inform statuses to define the involvement of stakeholders in project activities.
Using logic and reasoning to drive decision making.
A determination of the ability and the interest of an organization to transition to the future state.
A decision-making thought process that looks to reduce the number of decisions needing to be made in the short term and delays decision making until as late as is possible to reduce uncertainties.

front: What are Recommended Changes to Requirements and Other Product Information?
back: The course of action that is proposed after analyzing all of the impacts associated to making a proposed change.
original_term: Recommended Changes to Requirements and Other Product Information

front: What is a Recommended Solution Option?
back: The solution choice determined the best approach for addressing the business need.
Testing conducted to validate that new or enhanced functionality will not impact existing functionality.
A requirement imposed by a governmental body.
The criteria established by a governmental or industry or organizational body as to what constitutes compliance with rules and constraints.
Social skills that enable one to develop partnerships and to operate as an effective member of a team or a group.
The linkages established between objects, like components of product information, deliverables, and project work.
A technique for creating estimates that are derived from performing a comparison against a similar body of work rather than estimating based on absolute units of cost or time.
One or more components of one or more products, which are intended to be put into production at the same time.
An agreement to either permit the release or partial release of the solution, delay it, or disapprove and prevent it.

front: What is the Releasing Process Group?
back: The business analysis process performed to determine whether all or part of a solution should be released and to obtain acceptance that all or part of a solution is ready to be transitioned to an operational team that will take ongoing responsibility for it.
The capability of a product to operate error free, to maintain its level of performance under stated conditions, or for a stated period or percentage of time.
A business analysis model that documents, in a tabular format, all of the requirements necessary to develop a single report.

front: What are Reporting and Analysis Tools?
back: A category of tools used in business analysis for processing, analyzing, and reporting information at different levels of granularity.

front: What are Required Capabilities and Features?
back: The list of net changes the organization will need to obtain in order to achieve the desired future state.
A condition or capability that is necessary to be present in a product, service, or result to satisfy a business need.
An attribute of a requirement that identifies where the requirement falls within the requirements life cycle, for example, in-process, approved, deferred, or rejected.
Describes how requirements, models, and other product information or elements of those relate to each other.
A property of a requirement used to store descriptive information about the requirement, such as last change date, author, source, etc.

front: What is a Requirements Change Process?
back: The process that defines how changes to requirements will be handled.
The process of specifying requirements and other types of product information at the appropriate level of detail, format, and level of formality.
A record of product requirements and other product information, along with whatever is recorded to manage it.

The activity of drawing out information from stakeholders and other sources for the purpose of further understanding the needs of the business, to address a problem or opportunity and the stakeholder's preferences and conditions for the solution that will address those needs.
The flow or life of a requirement throughout a portfolio, program, or project.

front: What is a Requirements Management Tool?
back: A software product that allows for the capture and storage of requirements and other product information in a repository.
The culmination of a set of product information that is used to communicate information about the solution at a specific point in time.

front: What is a Requirements Traceability Matrix?
back: A grid that links product requirements from their origin to the deliverables that satisfy them.
The process of ensuring that the solution satisfies its intended use and anticipated value, ensuring the correct solution is delivered.
An ability to elicit useful information from relevant sources in a timely and effective manner.
Using alternative or creative means to elicit information and solve problems, especially when a clear or conventional solution is not available.
A type of meeting in which participants explore their work and results in order to improve both process and product.
The percent return on an initial investment, calculated by taking the projected average of all net benefits and dividing them by the initial cost.
The degree of uncertainty an organization or individual is willing to accept in anticipation of a reward.

front: What is a Risk Burndown Chart?
back: On adaptive projects, risk burndown charts are used to show the status of risks across iterations.
An aggregate measure of the potential impact of all risks at any given point in time in a project, program, or portfolio.
A repository in which outputs of risk management processes are recorded.
A sprint or iteration specifically designated for research to address product risks.
In business analysis, a role represents a defined function to be performed by a product team member, such as research, analyze, model, specify, review, or update.
An iterative planning technique in which the work to be accomplished in the near term is planned in detail, while the work in the future is planned at a higher level.
An analytical technique used to determine the basic underlying reason that causes a variance, a defect, or a risk.
A model of concepts and behaviors that defines or constrains aspects of a business in order to enforce established business policies.
A case of usage of a solution often manifested as a concrete example of a use case or user story or several functional requirements specified in the sequence in which they occur.
In business analysis, scope is defined as the boundary for the solution, whereas in project management, it is defined as the sum of the products, services, and results to be provided as a project.
The uncontrolled expansion of a product or project scope without adjustments to time, cost, and resources.
A type of model that identifies the boundaries of the project, program, product, and/or system under analysis.
A type of adaptive life cycle where a solution is built in small incremental portions and each cycle of development builds upon the last version of the product.
A portion of a product that is to be delivered in an iteration, a sprint, or a release.

front: What is Select and Approve Requirements?
back: The process of facilitating discussions with stakeholders to negotiate and confirm which requirements should be incorporated within an iteration, release, or project.
A modeling technique that describes how user or system processes interact with one another across any involved users or systems and the order in which the processes or steps are performed.
Being capable of identifying how one's actions are perceived by others.
The performance of duties or work for another party.
Consists of the compilation of all the information discussed and shared across the product team during collaboration.
Testing a solution in a separate environment that is production-like, reduced in size, and contains small representative, cohesive samples of any data that are part of that environment.
A condition that may be an internal problem or external opportunity that forms the basis of a business need and might result in a portfolio component, program, or project to address the condition.
An objective statement of a problem or opportunity that includes the statement itself, the situation's effect on the organization, and the ultimate impact.
Something that is produced to deliver measurable business value to meet the business need and expectations of stakeholders.

front: What is a Solution Capability Matrix?
back: A model that provides a simple, visual way to examine capabilities and solution components in one view.
Specifications and diagrams, typically based on business analysis findings, which describe how the solution will be implemented.

front: What is the Solution Evaluation Knowledge Area?
back: Includes the processes for validating a full solution, or a segment of a solution, that is about to be, or has already been implemented to determine how well a solution meets the business needs and delivers value to the organization.

front: What is a Solution Evaluation Approach?
back: Describes when and how a solution will be evaluated, the types of metrics that will support evaluation, the feasibility of collecting and communicating the actual performance data for these metrics, and who is responsible for conducting the evaluation and communicating results.
An approach for addressing a business need.
A requirement that describes the features, functions, and characteristics of a product, which will meet business and stakeholder requirements.
An individual who plays a highly focused role within a portfolio, program, or project such as an architect or a release manager.
An elicitation technique that uses game play to elicit information about product features that stakeholders find problematic.
An elicitation technique that uses game play to discover unknown relationships between the product being analyzed and other products.
A short time interval within a project, usually of fixed length, during which a team conducts research or prototypes an aspect of a solution to prove its viability.
An individual or group that provides resources and support for the project, program, or portfolio and is accountable for enabling success.
A short time interval within a project, usually of fixed length, during which a team commits to deliver a specified production-ready segment of a solution to its sponsors.
An individual, group, or organization that may affect, be affected by, or perceive itself to be affected by a decision, activity, or outcome of a project, program, or portfolio.
A technique of systematically gathering and analyzing quantitative and qualitative information to determine whose interests should be taken into account throughout an initiative.
The qualities and attributes of a stakeholder, which together determine aspects of how the stakeholder behaves.

front: What is a Stakeholder Engagement and Communication Approach?
back: Describes how best to effectively involve, interact, and communicate with stakeholders.

front: What is the Stakeholder Engagement Knowledge Area?
back: Includes the processes for identifying and analyzing those who have an interest in the outcome of the solution to determine how to collaborate and communicate with them.
A collection of stakeholders who have similar likes, interests, and characteristics.
The process of determining the stakeholders impacted by a business problem or opportunity.
A technique used to visually analyze stakeholders and their relationship to each other and to the problem or opportunity under analysis.
A technique that uses a quadrant or matrix to analyze a set of stakeholders.
A project document that includes the identification, assessment, and classification of project stakeholders.
A requirement that describes the needs of a stakeholder or stakeholder group.
A document established by an authority, custom, or general consent as a model or example.
A data model used to show the valid states of an object and allowed transitions between them.
A data model used to show the valid states of an object and allowed transitions between them.
A prototyping technique that shows sequence or navigation through a series of images or illustrations.

The process by which user stories are supplemented with additional information from conversations with business stakeholders until they are sufficiently detailed for product development to begin work.

A technique used to sequence user stories, based upon their business value and the order in which their users typically perform them, so that teams can arrive at a shared understanding of what will be built.
A unit used to estimate the relative level of effort needed to implement a user story.
A technique to split epics or user stories from a higher level to a lower level.

front: What is a Subject Matter Expert (SME)?
back: A person who is considered an expert in a particular subject area.
Measures that can be used to determine solution success.

The process of collaborating on charter development with the sponsoring entity and stakeholder resources using the business analysis knowledge, experience, and product information acquired during needs assessment and business case development efforts.
The ease at which a solution can be maintained and managed by the organization over time, including the cost and level of effort.
Analysis of strengths, weaknesses, opportunities, and threats of an organization, initiative, or option.
A collection of various components that together can produce results not obtainable by the individual components alone.

front: What is a System Interface Table?
back: A model that depicts the requirements for the connections between interfacing systems, including how they are connected and what information flows between them.
The ability to analyze from both a holistic and detailed point of view.
Personal knowledge that can be difficult to articulate and share such as beliefs, experience, and insights.

front: What is Team and Subject Matter Expert Knowledge?
back: Knowledge that is usually not fully and formally documented but instead resides in the minds of individuals or groups.
original_term: Team and Subject Matter Expert Knowledge

back: The accumulation of architectural and design and construction shortcuts during product development, which tend to make a product more difficult to maintain and enhance.
A defined systematic procedure employed by a human resource to perform an activity to produce a product or result or deliver a service, and that may employ one or more tools.

An analysis to determine the extent to which a technology exists in an organization to support a potential solution and, if not present, how feasible it would be to acquire and operate the needed technology.
A partially completed document in a predefined format that provides a defined structure for collecting, organizing, and presenting information and data.
A 'test-first' approach that defines requirements in terms of test cases and then constructs a solution which can pass the tests.
An analysis to determine how well a proposed solution can be delivered to meet the organization's needed timeframe.
Having a limit or constraint that is based on a point in time.
An estimation or planning technique that can be used during prioritization by setting a strict time limit and prioritizing only the work the team can complete in that duration of time.
The ability to stay organized, be productive, estimate and sequence work, and plan effectively.
Something tangible, such as a template or software program, used in performing an activity to produce a product or result.
In business analysis, represents the collective knowledge a practitioner possesses about the toolset they utilize to perform their work.
The ability to track information across the product life cycle by establishing linkages between objects.

front: What is the Traceability and Monitoring Knowledge Area?
back: Includes the processes for tracing, approving, and assessing changes to product information to manage it throughout the business analysis effort.

front: What is a Traceability and Monitoring Approach?
back: Defines how the traceability and change management activities will be performed throughout the portfolio, program, project, or product.
Defines the activities required to transition from the current to future state.
A requirement that is a temporary capability, such as data conversion and training requirements, needed to transition from the current as-is state to the future state.
A guiding framework for conducting activities that are needed to transition from a current state to a future state.
As an act or event, anything that serves as a stimulus and initiates or precipitates a reaction or series of reactions.
A personal characteristic that signifies a person is trustworthy, competent, reliable, and held in high regard by others.
The business analysis information obtained from completed elicitation activities that have not yet been agreed upon and validated for accuracy by the product team.

An analysis model that describes a flow of actor-system interactions and boundaries for those interactions, including trigger, initiating and participating actors, and preconditions and post conditions.

front: What is a Use Case Diagram?
back: A business analysis model that shows all of the in-scope use cases for a solution and which actors have a part in those use cases.
A type of stakeholder or actor who will use the product.
A group of stakeholders who are users of a product and are grouped together due to the similarity in their requirements and use of the product.

front: What is a User Experience Analyst?
back: Also referred to as user interface analysts; individuals who are responsible for studying user behavior, preferences, and constraints to identify user interface and usability requirements for software applications and other products.
Anything that supports the interaction between a person and service that is provided to that person.

The art and science of creating a user interface that meets users' interface requirements while exploiting the features of overall organizational best practices related to how humans interact with the chosen type of interface.
A business analysis model that shows the specific pages or screens of an application and how a user can navigate between them.
A one or two sentence description written from the viewpoint of the actor that describes a function that is needed.
The process of checking that the requirements meet business goals and objectives.

front: What are Validated Requirements and Other Product Information?
back: Product information that the stakeholders agree meet the business goals and objectives.
original_term: Validated Requirements and Other Product Information

back: The assurance that a product, service, or result meets the needs of the customer and other identified stakeholders.
A technique used to quantify the return or value that an option will provide.
A measure of the worth of a benefit.
A variation of process flows that can be used to locate delays, queues, or handoffs occurring in current processes.
A measure of expected team productivity, typically expressed as the total story points expected to be delivered during an iteration or sprint.
A quantifiable deviation, departure, or divergence from a known baseline or expected value.
A technique for determining the cause and degree of difference between the baseline and actual performance.
An evaluation of vendors and their products or services offered to understand the viability, strengths, weaknesses, and risks of each vendor solution.
The evaluation of whether or not a product, service, or result complies with a regulation, requirement, specification, or imposed condition.

front: What are Verified Requirements and Other Product Information?
back: Product information that has been evaluated to assure it is free from errors and addresses the quality standards to which the information will be held.
original_term: Verified Requirements and Other Product Information

back: The process of checking that requirements are of sufficient quality.
The process of maintaining a history of changes on software or documentation.

front: What is a Version Control System (VCS)?
back: A system that is used to track the history of revisions, often but not always related to software.

front: What is a Viable Design Option?
back: A design option that has been reviewed by stakeholders and determined to be a feasible means for achieving the business goals and objectives.
The ability to communicate through the use of models and visual representations and knowing when best to use these representations over the spoken or written words.
A summarized, high-level description about the expectations for a product such as target market, users, major benefits, and what differentiates the product from others in the market.
A foundational part of a story map representing the full set of end-to-end functionality that the stakeholders require for the solution to be accepted or functional.
A technique used to review or share a set of information with stakeholders to obtain feedback or approval.
An agreed-upon interval during which a solution released to production is maintained by the team that developed it before it is turned over to the business operational area which owns it.
An example of predictive project life cycle.
Evaluation criteria that is adjusted by applying a multiplier to signify how important the criterion is to the decision-making process.
A technique to weight, rate, and score each criterion against a set of options used to add objectivity when formulating a decision or recommendation.

front: What is a Weighted Ranking Matrix?
back: A table used when performing the weighted ranking technique to weight, rate, and score each criteria against a set of options.

front: What is Weighted Shortest Job First (WSJF)?
back: A method used primarily in adaptive frameworks to rank user stories based on more dimensions than just business value and effort.

A variation of the Delphi technique which is sometimes used to bring convergence to widely differing estimates that have been developed separately for the same work item by a number of different individuals.
A diagram that represents a static blueprint or schematic of a user interface and is used to identify basic functionality.
A hierarchical decomposition of the total scope of work to be carried out by the project team to accomplish the project objectives and create the required deliverables.
Being capable of completing tasks independently and being motivated and driven to do what needs to be done without being asked.

front: What is Work in Progress Limit?
back: An agreed-upon maximum number of product backlog items that can be in a given state of the development workflow at the same time within the same project.
An output produced as a result of some completion of work.

front: What is a PMO (Project Management Office)?
back: Organizational entities, typically established as departments or teams, primarily tasked with centralizing activities related to the management of portfolios, programs, and/or projects.
A PMO specifically designed to support agile project management methodologies, focusing on fostering agile practices, principles, and values.

front: What is a Control Tower PMO?
back: A PMO with an active role in project management, overseeing practices, monitoring performance, and auditing projects to ensure compliance with established policies and processes.
A PMO that focuses on providing expert advice, guidance, and support to project teams within an organization, emphasizing a proactive advisory role.
A PMO with a moderate-to-high level of control that enforces compliance with established project management policies, methodologies, and frameworks.
A PMO specific to a particular department or business unit, providing support and guidance tailored to that department's needs.
A PMO with a high level of control that actively manages and directs projects within the organization, often having authority over project managers.
A PMO responsible for managing and delivering projects, providing necessary tools and resources with a focus on ensuring projects are delivered on time, within budget, and to quality standards.
A high-level PMO with broad scope and authority responsible for overseeing and coordinating all PMO activities and ensuring alignment with strategic objectives across the organization.
A PMO responsible for the management of projects within a specific functional area or domain, such as IT, human resources, or finance.
A PMO that combines elements of different PMO types based on the specific needs and context of the organization.
A PMO focused on driving experimentation by supporting projects and initiatives aimed at fostering innovation, creativity, and new product development.
A PMO focused on supporting individual projects and project teams, providing guidance, tools, and resources for successful execution.

front: What is a Portfolio Management Office (Pf-PMO)?
back: A PMO responsible for managing the organization's entire portfolio of programs, projects, and work, ensuring alignment with strategy and optimizing resource allocation.

front: What is a Program Management Office (Pg-PMO)?
back: A PMO responsible for managing and coordinating multiple related projects that are part of a larger program to ensure objectives and benefits are achieved.
A PMO established to support a single, large-scale, or high-risk project (sometimes called a project controls office).

front: What is a Project Support Office (PSO)?
back: A PMO that provides administrative support and coordination for individual projects and project teams, handling tasks like tracking, reporting, and documentation.

front: What is a Project Management Center of Excellence (PMCoE)?
back: A specialized PMO dedicated to promoting and enhancing an organization's project management capabilities, knowledge, skills, and accepted practices.
A PMO focused on providing support to project teams through tools, templates, accepted practices, and training, typically with a low level of control.
A PMO focused on aligning the organization's portfolios, programs, and projects with strategic objectives and ensuring they deliver value.
A PMO responsible for managing and coordinating multiple related projects, ensuring processes are followed and good practices are shared.

front: What is a Transformation Management Office (TMO)?
back: A PMO that drives and manages large-scale organizational change initiatives to ensure alignment with the organization's vision.

front: What is a Value Management Office (VMO)?
back: A PMO responsible for ensuring projects deliver maximum value to the organization, focusing on evaluation, prioritization, and tracking of benefits.
A concept where the PMO's traditional focus is extended to other areas of the organization (e.g., change management office) to support strategic objectives and cross-functional collaboration.
An organizational context where the organization recognizes the benefits of a PMO but lacks the necessary cultural foundation or maturity to implement one effectively.
An organizational context where the organization has achieved a baseline level of cultural readiness and executive buy-in to initiate a PMO.
An organizational context where the PMO begins to scale operations, refine processes, and deliver initial customer benefits.
An organizational context representing the peak of organizational project management performance where the PMO generates substantial value and widespread recognition.
An organizational context where the organization faces challenges impacting the PMO's value proposition, leading to waning stakeholder support.
An organizational context where the PMO loses support rapidly, struggles to demonstrate value, and faces intensifying resistance.
An organizational context where the PMO ceases to function effectively or becomes obsolete due to lack of backing and resources.
An organizational context where the PMO idea is reborn, potentially leading to a more robust PMO if managed correctly.
An entity that offers specialized services to meet the specific needs of its customers, delivering value through intangible benefits.
A PMO that adopts business agility principles to remain flexible and responsive to changing organizational needs.
Stakeholders within an organization that directly receive, use, or benefit from the services provided by the PMO.
A broad group including anyone who has an interest in or is affected by the PMO's activities, whether they directly use its services or not.
A strategic approach to business decisions, operations, and interactions that places customers at the core, prioritizing the fulfillment of their needs.
The strategic management of all programs and projects within an organization, including planning, prioritization, and alignment with strategy.
The coordinated management of multiple related projects aligned to achieve a common goal.
The management of individual projects to ensure they are completed on time, within budget, and to required quality standards.
A service approach where the PMO acts as an advisor, providing expert advice while customers maintain full control over decisions.
A service approach where the PMO offers practical assistance, tools, and resources while customers retain significant control.
A service approach where the PMO facilitates activities with customers through collaborative sessions, fostering shared goals.
A service approach where the PMO implements standardized processes and provides clear guidelines that customers must follow.
A service approach where the PMO oversees and regulates processes, maintaining control and authority to make decisions.
A service approach where the PMO takes full responsibility for managing specific activities, leaving customers with minimal control over execution.
The sophistication and effectiveness with which a PMO delivers its services and contributes to organizational success.
Areas of expertise required for effective PMO operation, categorized into design, operation, and improvement.
The domain focusing on the design and development of PMO services to ensure strategic alignment and effectiveness.
The domain involving the day-to-day management and execution of PMO services to ensure consistency and quality.
The domain focusing on refining and optimizing PMO services to enhance efficiency and value delivery.
The framework that defines decision-making processes, roles, responsibilities, and accountability measures specifically for the PMO entity.
Policies and standards governing the selection, prioritization, and management of an organization's collection of programs and projects.
Policies and standards overseeing the coordination and management of related projects to ensure collective benefits.
The framework of policies and decision-making structures guiding the planning, execution, and control of a single project.
A formal declaration that defines the PMO's purpose, scope, authority, and responsibility within the organizational context.
A comprehensive plan outlining how the PMO will deliver value to its stakeholders over the short, medium, and long term.
Essential elements that form the foundation of a PMO, including PMO mandate, PMO strategy, and PMO governance.

front: What is the PMO Value Ring™ Framework?
back: A comprehensive model for creating and operating value-driven, customer-centric PMOs.
The initial step in the value-generating PMO flywheel focused on educating stakeholders about the PMO's role, capabilities, and potential value.
The process of identifying and evaluating the specific requirements and pain points of PMO customers.
A clear statement articulating how the PMO will address identified needs and add value to the organization.
The process of creating, refining, and evolving PMO services to meet customer needs and organizational objectives.
The process of introducing newly developed or improved PMO services to their intended users within the organization.
The day-to-day management and execution of PMO services to deliver value to customers.
The process of tracking, measuring, and evaluating PMO services against predetermined standards.
The process of enhancing the maturity and effectiveness of PMO services to increase their value and impact.
The process of realizing and demonstrating the tangible benefits that PMO services provide to the organization.
The process of ensuring that customers not only receive value from PMO services but also acknowledge and appreciate it.

front: What is Customer Perception of Value?
back: A subjective evaluation by PMO customers of the benefits they receive from PMO services relative to their expectations and needs.

front: What is a Customer Value Agreement?
back: A formal document outlining the specific outcomes and value the PMO commits to delivering to each major customer or customer group.
The third phase in the PMO customer experience cycle where designed services are implemented and rolled out to customers.
The second phase in the PMO customer experience cycle where insights from exploration are transformed into service concepts and plans.
The fourth phase in the PMO customer experience cycle focused on continuously improving and refining PMO services.
Signs or symptoms indicating that a customer may be facing challenges in a specific area; used to identify potential PMO service opportunities.
The initial phase in the PMO customer experience cycle focused on understanding the current landscape, customer needs, and potential opportunities.
The unique characteristics, challenges, and good practices of the organization's industry that influence PMO operations.
Foundational components that influence PMO design and operation, including organizational strategy, structure, culture, and industry-specific profile.
Distinct states or situations that an organization may experience, influencing how a PMO operates and delivers value.

front: What is PMO as a Service Provider?
back: A perspective that views the PMO as an internal service provider, focusing on meeting customer needs and delivering value rather than just enforcing processes.
The ongoing process of enhancing the skills, knowledge, and abilities of the PMO team to improve service delivery and value creation.

front: What is the PMO Customer Experience Cycle?
back: A model representing the stages a PMO goes through in interacting with and delivering value to its customers.
The practice of dividing PMO customers into groups based on their needs, maturity levels, or other relevant characteristics.
The specific benefits or results that PMO customers expect to achieve through the use of PMO services.

front: What is a PMO Risk Management Plan?
back: A strategy for identifying, assessing, and mitigating risks specific to PMO operations and value delivery.
Different methods of delivering PMO services, ranging from consultative to directive, and tailored to customer needs and organizational context.

front: What is a PMO Service Catalog?
back: A comprehensive list of services offered by the PMO, including their descriptions, benefits, and delivery approaches.
The level of sophistication and effectiveness of individual PMO services, assessed on a scale to guide improvement efforts.

front: What are PMO Service Performance Metrics?
back: Specific, measurable indicators used to assess the effectiveness and efficiency of PMO services.

front: What is the PMO Value Journey?
back: A mapped progression of how the PMO's value proposition to its customers will evolve over time.
The final phase in the PMO customer experience cycle where the PMO's impact on the organization comes into sharp focus and value is demonstrated.
A formal agreement between the PMO and its customers defining the expected level of service.
The process of ensuring PMO activities and services directly support and contribute to the organization's strategic objectives.

front: What is the Value-generating PMO Flywheel?
back: A model that breaks down the PMO customer experience cycle into 10 actionable steps.
The act of formally receiving or acknowledging something and regarding it as being true, sound, suitable, or complete.
A component of work performed during the course of a project.
The act of formally confirming, sanctioning, ratifying, or agreeing to something.
Information that is both concrete and tangible, such as a document or electronic file.

A planned and documented activity performed by qualified personnel to determine by investigation, examination, or evaluation of objective evidence, the adequacy and compliance with established procedures or applicable documents and the effectiveness of implementation.

The approved time phased plan (for a project, a work breakdown structure component, a work package, or a schedule activity), plus or minus approved project scope, cost, schedule, and technical changes.
Any occurrence of deviation from expected outcomes, where the deliverable is performing to specifications and the specifications are in error.
Identifying, documenting, approving or rejecting, and controlling changes to the project baselines.

front: What is a Change Control Board (CCB)?
back: A formally constituted group of stakeholders responsible for reviewing, evaluating, approving, delaying, or rejecting changes to the project, with all decisions and recommendations being recorded.
A description of how and why a revision of a configuration item differs from its prior version.

front: What is a Change Implementation Board?
back: A formally constituted group of stakeholders responsible for reviewing, evaluating, approving, delaying, or rejecting changes to the project based on implementation reasons such as schedule or cost.
A grouping of change requests, normally based on like changes or changes to the same area of the project's deliverables.

front: What is a Change Review Board?
back: A formally constituted group of stakeholders responsible for reviewing, evaluating, approving, delaying, or rejecting changes to the project based on business reasons such as strategic focus or business implementation plans.
Requests to expand or reduce the project scope, modify policies, processes, plans, or procedures, modify costs or budgets, or revise schedules.
Physical and functional arrangement of interconnected parts that form a system, a piece of equipment or a product.

Ensures (1) regulation of the flow of proposed changes, (2) documentation of the complete impact of the proposed changes, and (3) release only of approved configuration changes into project products and their related configuration documentation.

The application of agreed upon rules in order to ensure that all modifications to configuration items are submitted and analyzed prior to providing a disposition and that all such requests and changes are recorded in a traceable manner.
Selection of configuration items, and identification of their functional and physical characteristics.

Aggregation of hardware, software, processed materials, services, or any of its discrete portions, which satisfy an end-use function, and whose requirements are specific and designated for separate configuration management.
Management process to establish and maintain consistency of a product's performance, functional and physical attributes with its requirements, design, and operational information throughout its life.

Describes a condition where the configuration management system on a project manages unique configuration items in a way to ensure they do not conflict in practice, schedule, or resource usage; and where they share a common vocabulary needed for effective communications among stakeholders.

front: What is a Configuration Management Plan?
back: Configuration planning which outlines the overall processes and procedures to be employed for configuration management.
The development and planning of configuration management processes for the context and environment in which they are to be performed.
An element of configuration management that consists of the recording and reporting of information needed to effectively manage a configuration item.

front: What is Configuration Verification and Audit?
back: The process of ensuring the result of a configuration item meets pre-defined criteria (requirements).
Specification of the point at which a change will be effective.
Any condition where a stakeholder (customer, user, developer, etc.) finds an area that may be enhanced or improved.
