front: What is an Enterprise Configuration Management Plan?
back: Configuration planning which outlines the overall processes and procedures to be employed for configuration management at an organization or portfolio level.

front: What is a Functional Configuration Audit?
back: An audit conducted to verify that the development of a configuration item has been completed satisfactorily; that it is operational or useable; and that the support documents are complete and satisfactory.
The process of reviewing all change requests, approving changes and controlling changes to deliverables and organizational process assets.

front: What is a Physical Configuration Audit?
back: An audit conducted to verify that a configuration item (or group of configuration items) matches documented descriptions and requirements.
Any occurrence of deviation from expected outcomes, where the deliverable is not performing to defined specifications.

A subset of project management that comprises the collective body of processes, activities, tools, and methods used to manage designated project deliverables or artifacts throughout the project life cycle.

front: What is a Project Configuration Management Plan?
back: A subsidiary of the project management plan that can also be a subset of the enterprise configuration management plan, and will use the enterprise plan as a guideline to ensure compliance and integration with an organization's overall plans.
An action whereby a particular version of a configuration item or group of configuration items is made available.

Person or organization (e.g., customer, sponsor, performing organization, or the public) that is actively involved in the project, or whose interests may be positively or negatively affected by execution or completion of the project.

front: What is a Technical Review Board?
back: A formally or informally constituted group of subject matter experts within the project responsible for reviewing, evaluating, approving, delaying, or rejecting changes to the project based on technical reasons such as capabilities and functionality.
The technique of evaluating a component or product at the end of a phase or project to assure or confirm it satisfies the conditions imposed.
A uniquely identified instance of a configuration item.
A means to identify and manage configuration items as they change over time.

Machine behavior and function that exhibits human intelligence and behavior. More specifically, it is the ability of machines to perceive, understand, learn, make decisions, converse, and develop intuition.

Also known as 'strong AI,' this refers to systems enabled with cognitive capabilities and mental dexterity that mimic humans, allowing them to generalize knowledge across domains and adapt to changes.
AI systems designed to use technologies to perform specific, limited tasks (e.g., chatbots, facial recognition) and cannot be applied to other tasks.
The idea of machines and humans working together to enhance, rather than replace, human tasks.
A specific competency that an organization needs to have in order to implement and sustain OPM.
original_definition: A specific competency that an organization needs to have in order to implement and sustain OPM.

back: A system of practices, techniques, procedures, and rules used by those who work in a discipline.
original_definition: A system of practices, techniques, procedures, and rules used by those who work in a discipline.

back: An entity that may include all levels of the enterprise and may transcend business lines or divisions, including any area or business unit that has impact, influence, or involvement in project and business operations.
original_definition: An entity that may include all levels of the enterprise and may transcend business lines or divisions, including any area/business unit that has impact, influence, or involvement in project and business operations.

back: A structural, cultural, technological, or human-resource practice that the performing organization can use to achieve strategic objectives.
original_definition: A structural, cultural, technological, or human-resource practice that the performing organization can use to achieve strategic objectives.

back: Plans, processes, policies, procedures, and knowledge bases specific to and used by the performing organization.
original_definition: Plans, processes, policies, procedures, and knowledge bases specific to and used by the performing organization.

back: A framework in which portfolio, program, and project management are integrated with organizational enablers in order to achieve strategic objectives.
original_definition: A framework in which portfolio, program, and project management are integrated with organizational enablers in order to achieve strategic objectives.

front: What is Organizational Project Management Maturity (OPM Maturity)?
back: The level of an organization's ability to deliver the desired strategic outcomes in a predictable, controllable, and reliable manner.
original_definition: The level of an organization's ability to deliver the desired strategic outcomes in a predictable, controllable, and reliable manner.

front: What is an Organizational Project Management Methodology (OPM Methodology)?
back: A system of practices, techniques, procedures, and rules used by those who work in OPM.
original_definition: A system of practices, techniques, procedures, and rules used by those who work in OPM.

back: Projects, programs, subsidiary portfolios, and operations managed as a group to achieve strategic objectives.
original_definition: Projects, programs, subsidiary portfolios, and operations managed as a group to achieve strategic objectives.

back: The centralized management of one or more portfolios to achieve strategic objectives.
original_definition: The centralized management of one or more portfolios to achieve strategic objectives.

back: Related projects, subsidiary programs, and program activities managed in a coordinated manner to obtain benefits not available from managing them individually.
original_definition: Related projects, subsidiary programs, and program activities managed in a coordinated manner to obtain benefits not available from managing them individually.

back: The application of knowledge, skills, and principles to a program to achieve the program objectives and to obtain benefits and control not available by managing program components individually.
original_definition: The application of knowledge, skills, and principles to a program to achieve the program objectives and to obtain benefits and control not available by managing program components individually.

front: What is a Program Management Office?
back: A management structure that standardizes the program-related governance processes and facilitates the sharing of resources, methodologies, tools, and techniques.
original_definition: A management structure that standardizes the program-related governance processes and facilitates the sharing of resources, methodologies, tools, and techniques.

back: A temporary endeavor undertaken to create a unique product, service, or result.
original_definition: A temporary endeavor undertaken to create a unique product, service, or result.

back: The application of knowledge, skills, tools, and techniques to project activities to meet the project requirements.
original_definition: The application of knowledge, skills, tools, and techniques to project activities to meet the project requirements.

front: What is a Project Management Methodology?
back: A system of practices, techniques, procedures, and rules used by those who work in portfolios, programs, and projects.
original_definition: A system of practices, techniques, procedures, and rules used by those who work in portfolios, programs, and projects.

front: What is a Project Management Office (PMO)?
back: A management structure that standardizes the program-related governance processes and facilitates the sharing of resources, methodologies, tools, and techniques.
original_definition: A management structure that standardizes the program-related governance processes and facilitates the sharing of resources, methodologies, tools, and techniques.

back: An individual or a group that provides resources and support for the project, program, or portfolio, and is accountable for enabling success.
original_definition: An individual or a group that provides resources and support for the project, program, or portfolio, and is accountable for enabling success.

back: An individual, group, or organization that may affect, be affected by, or perceive itself to be affected by a decision, activity, or outcome of a project, program, or portfolio.
original_definition: An individual, group, or organization that may affect, be affected by, or perceive itself to be affected by a decision, activity, or outcome of a project, program, or portfolio.

back: A characteristic of a process or state that can be maintained indefinitely.
original_definition: A characteristic of a process or state that can be maintained indefinitely.

back: A factor in the planning process considered to be true, real, or certain, without proof or demonstration.
original_definition: A factor in the planning process considered to be true, real, or certain, without proof or demonstration.

front: What is a Cause in risk management?
back: Events or circumstances that currently exist or are certain to exist in the future, which might give rise to risks.
original_definition: Events or circumstances that currently exist or are certain to exist in the future, which might give rise to risks.

back: A predetermined element of a portfolio or program that is work related to the achievement of the portfolio's or program's strategic objectives.
original_definition: A predetermined element of a portfolio or program that is work related to the achievement of the portfolio's or program's strategic objectives.

back: A factor that limits the options for managing a project, program, portfolio, or process.
original_definition: A factor that limits the options for managing a project, program, portfolio, or process.

back: A document that describes actions to take if predetermined trigger conditions occur.
original_definition: A document that describes actions to take if predetermined trigger conditions occur.

back: Time or money allocated in the schedule or cost baseline for known risks with active response strategies.
original_definition: Time or money allocated in the schedule or cost baseline for known risks with active response strategies.

back: A risk that arises which could not have been identified earlier on.
original_definition: A risk that arises which could not have been identified earlier on.

back: An approach to managing risk that reflects the organization's culture, capability, and strategy to create and sustain value.
original_definition: An approach to managing risk that reflects the organization's culture, capability, and strategy to create and sustain value.

back: Determining and documenting the risks that might affect the intended outcomes.
original_definition: The process of determining and documenting the risks that might affect the intended outcomes.

front: What is Impact in risk management?
back: A measure of the effect of a risk on one or more objectives if it occurs.
original_definition: A measure of the effect of a risk on one or more objectives if it occurs.

back: A current threat that may have an impact on one or more objectives.
original_definition: A current threat that may have an impact on one or more objectives.

back: Time or money that management sets aside in addition to the schedule or cost baseline and releases for unforeseen work that is within the scope of the project.
original_definition: Time or money that management sets aside in addition to the schedule or cost baseline and releases for unforeseen work that is within the scope of the project.

back: A risk that would have a positive effect on one or more objectives.
original_definition: A risk that would have a positive effect on one or more objectives.

front: What is Organizational Project Management in risk context?
back: A framework in which portfolio, program, and project management are integrated with organizational enablers in order to achieve strategic objectives.
original_definition: A framework in which portfolio, program, and project management are integrated with organizational enablers in order to achieve strategic objectives.

back: The effect of uncertainty on the portfolio, program, or project as a whole.
original_definition: The effect of uncertainty on the portfolio, program, or project as a whole.

front: What is a Portfolio in risk management?
back: Projects, programs, subsidiary portfolios, and operations managed as a group to achieve strategic objectives.
original_definition: Projects, programs, subsidiary portfolios, and operations managed as a group to achieve strategic objectives.

front: What is Portfolio Management in risk management?
back: The centralized management of one or more portfolios to achieve strategic objectives.
original_definition: The centralized management of one or more portfolios to achieve strategic objectives.

front: What is Probability in risk analysis?
back: A measure of how likely an individual risk is to occur.
original_definition: A measure of how likely an individual risk is to occur.

front: What is a Program in risk management?
back: Related projects, subsidiary programs, and program activities managed in a coordinated manner to obtain benefits not available from managing them individually.
original_definition: Related projects, subsidiary programs, and program activities managed in a coordinated manner to obtain benefits not available from managing them individually.

front: What is Program Management in risk management?
back: The application of knowledge, skills, and principles to a program to achieve the program objectives and to obtain benefits and control not available by managing program components individually.
original_definition: The application of knowledge, skills, and principles to a program to achieve the program objectives and to obtain benefits and control not available by managing program components individually.

front: What is a Project in risk management?
back: A temporary endeavor undertaken to create a unique product, service, or result.
original_definition: A temporary endeavor undertaken to create a unique product, service, or result.

front: What is Project Management in risk management?
back: The application of knowledge, skills, tools, and techniques to project activities to meet the project requirements.
original_definition: The application of knowledge, skills, tools, and techniques to project activities to meet the project requirements.

back: The consideration of characteristics such as probability, impact, manageability, timing of impacts, relationships with other risks, and common causes or effects.
original_definition: The consideration of a range of characteristics such as probability of occurrence, degree of impact on the objectives, manageability, timing of possible impacts, relationships with other risks, and common causes or effects.

back: The combined effect of identified risks on the desired outcome.
original_definition: The combined effect of identified risks on the desired outcome.

back: The risk that remains after risk responses have been implemented.
original_definition: The risk that remains after risk responses have been implemented.

back: A high-level approach to address an individual risk or overall risk, broken down into a set of risk actions.
original_definition: A high-level approach to address an individual risk or overall risk, broken down into a set of risk actions.

back: An uncertain event or condition that, if it occurs, has a positive or negative effect on one or more objectives.
original_definition: An uncertain event or condition that, if it occurs, has a positive or negative effect on one or more objectives.

back: A risk response that involves acknowledging the risk and taking no action unless it occurs.
original_definition: A risk response that involves acknowledging the risk and taking no action unless it occurs.

back: A detailed task that implements, in whole or in part, a response strategy in order to address an individual risk or overall risk.
original_definition: A detailed task that implements, in whole or in part, a response strategy in order to address an individual risk or overall risk.

front: Who is a Risk Action Owner?
back: The person or people responsible for carrying out the approved risk actions when responding to a given risk.
original_definition: The person(s) responsible for carrying out the approved risk actions when responding to a given risk.

back: The activities related to defining the characteristics of a risk and the degree to which it can impact objectives.
original_definition: The activities related to defining the characteristics of a risk and the degree to which it can impact objectives.

back: The degree of uncertainty an organization or individual is willing to accept in anticipation of a reward.
original_definition: The degree of uncertainty an organization or individual is willing to accept in anticipation of a reward.

back: The process of identifying, analyzing, and determining the probability of occurrence of a risk.
original_definition: The process of identifying, analyzing, and determining the probability of occurrence of a risk.

back: A disposition toward uncertainty, adopted explicitly or implicitly by individuals and groups, driven by perception, and evidenced by observable behavior.
original_definition: A disposition toward uncertainty, adopted explicitly or implicitly by individuals and groups, driven by perception, and evidenced by observable behavior.

back: A risk response that involves eliminating the threat or protecting the project, program, or portfolio from its impact.
original_definition: A risk response that involves eliminating the threat or protecting the project, program, or portfolio from its impact.

back: A risk response that involves increasing the probability of occurrence or impact of an opportunity.
original_definition: A risk response that involves increasing the probability of occurrence or impact of an opportunity.

back: A risk response that involves transferring the ownership of the risk to a relevant party in the organization because the risk is outside of scope or the team does not have sufficient authority to address it.
original_definition: A risk response that involves transferring the ownership of the risk to a relevant party in the organization because the risk is outside of scope or the team does not have sufficient authority to address it.

back: A risk response that involves ensuring that an opportunity occurs.
original_definition: A risk response that involves ensuring that an opportunity occurs.

back: An aggregate measure of the potential impact of all risks at any given point in time in a project, program, or portfolio.
original_definition: An aggregate measure of the potential impact of all risks at any given point in time in a project, program, or portfolio.

back: The process of locating and profiling the characteristics of risks related to work objectives.
original_definition: The process of locating and profiling the characteristics of risks related to work objectives.

back: The process that shapes decision making across the organization and within each domain and involves identifying, analyzing, responding to, and monitoring risks.
original_definition: The process that shapes decision making across the organization and within each of the domains and involves identifying, analyzing, responding to, and monitoring risks.

front: What is a Risk Management Framework?
back: A structure that organizes the process and activities of managing risks in an iterative fashion.
original_definition: A structure that organizes the process and activities of managing risks in an iterative fashion.

front: What is the Risk Management Life Cycle?
back: A structured approach for undertaking a comprehensive view of risk throughout the enterprise, portfolio, program, and project domains.
original_definition: A structured approach for undertaking a comprehensive view of risk throughout the enterprise, portfolio, program, and project domains.

front: What is a Risk Management Plan?
back: A component of the project, program, or portfolio management plan that describes how risk management activities will be structured and performed.
original_definition: A component of the project, program, or portfolio management plan that describes how risk management activities will be structured and performed.

back: A risk response that involves decreasing the probability or impact of a threat.
original_definition: A risk response that involves decreasing the probability or impact of a threat.

back: The person responsible for monitoring the risk and for selecting and implementing an appropriate risk response strategy.
original_definition: The person responsible for monitoring the risk and for selecting and implementing an appropriate risk response strategy.

back: A repository in which outputs of risk management processes are recorded.
original_definition: A repository in which outputs of risk management processes are recorded.

back: An action, planned or implemented, to address particular threats and opportunities.
original_definition: An action, planned or implemented, to address particular threats and opportunities.

back: A risk response that involves allocating ownership of an opportunity to a third party who is best able to capture the opportunity or absorb the impact of the threat.
original_definition: A risk response that involves allocating ownership of an opportunity to a third party who is best able to capture the opportunity or absorb the impact of the threat.

back: The measure of acceptable variation around an objective that reflects the risk appetite of the organization and stakeholders.
original_definition: The measure of acceptable variation around an objective that reflects the risk appetite of the organization and stakeholders.

back: A risk response that involves shifting the impact of a threat to a third party, together with ownership of the response.
original_definition: A risk response that involves shifting the impact of a threat to a third party, together with ownership of the response.

back: A risk that arises as a direct result of implementing a risk response.
original_definition: A risk that arises as a direct result of implementing a risk response.

front: Who is a Stakeholder in risk management?
back: An individual, group, or organization that may affect, be affected by, or perceive itself to be affected by a decision, activity, or outcome of a project, program, or portfolio.
original_definition: An individual, group, or organization that may affect, be affected by, or perceive itself to be affected by a decision, activity, or outcome of a project, program, or portfolio.

front: What is a Threat in risk management?
back: A risk that would have a negative effect on one or more objectives.
original_definition: A risk that would have a negative effect on one or more objectives.

back: An event or situation that indicates that a risk is about to occur.
original_definition: An event or situation that indicates that a risk is about to occur.
